title: The Asylum (Designated States) (Amendment) Order 2005
text:
The Asylum (Designated States) (Amendment) Order 2005	 	

Statutory Instrument 2005 No. 1016The Asylum (Designated States) (Amendment) Order 2005


© Crown Copyright 2005



Statutory Instruments printed from this website are printed under the superintendence and authority of the Controller of HMSO being the Queen's Printer of Acts of Parliament.


The legislation contained on this web site is subject to Crown Copyright protection. It may be reproduced free of charge provided that it is reproduced accurately and that the source and copyright status of the material is made evident to users.


It should be noted that the right to reproduce the text of Statutory Instruments does not extend to the Queen's Printer imprints which should be removed from any copies of the Statutory Instrument which are issued or made available to the public. This includes reproduction of the Statutory Instrument on the Internet and on intranet sites. The Royal Arms may be reproduced only where they are an integral part of the original document.




The text of this Internet version of the Statutory Instrument which is published by the Queen's Printer of Acts of Parliament has been prepared to reflect the text as it was Made. A print version is also available and is published by The Stationery Office Limited as the The Asylum (Designated States) (Amendment) Order 2005, ISBN 0110727436. The print version may be purchased by clicking  here.  Braille copies of this Statutory Instrument can also be purchased at the same price as the print edition by contacting TSO Customer Services on 0870 600 5522 or e-mail: customer.services@tso.co.uk.


Further information about the publication of legislation on this website can be found by referring to the Frequently Asked Questions. 


To ensure fast access over slow connections, large documents have been segmented into "chunks". Where you see a "continue" button at the bottom of the page of text, this indicates that there is another chunk of text available.




STATUTORY INSTRUMENTS



2005 No. 1016


IMMIGRATION


The Asylum (Designated States) (Amendment) Order 2005

	 	
Made	31st March 2005	 
	 	
Laid before Parliament	1st April 2005	 
	 	
Coming into force	22nd April 2005	 




The Secretary of State, in exercise of the powers conferred upon him by section 94(6) of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002[1], hereby makes the following Order:


    

1.
This Order may be cited as the Asylum (Designated States) (Amendment) Order 2005 and shall come into force on 22 April 2005.


    

2.
The list of States in section 94(4) of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002[2] is amended by omitting "(r) Bangladesh,".



Caroline Flint

Parliamentary Under Secretary of State



Home Office

31st March 2005





EXPLANATORY NOTE



(This note is not part of the Order)


Section 94 (Appeal from within United Kingdom: unfounded human rights or asylum claim) of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 ("the 2002 Act) concerns appeal rights for unfounded human rights or asylum claims.


Under section 94(2) of the 2002 Act, a person may not bring an appeal under section 82(1) of the 2002 Act while in the United Kingdom where he has made an asylum or human rights claim (or both) if the Secretary of State certifies that the claim or claims is or are clearly unfounded. The Secretary of State shall issue a certificate under section 94(2) of the 2002 Act if he is satisfied that the asylum claimant or human rights claimant is entitled to reside in a State listed in section 94(4) of the 2002 Act unless he is satisfied that the claim is not clearly unfounded.


This Order removes Bangladesh from the list of States in section 94(4) of the 2002 Act.



Notes:



[1] 
2002 c.41; section 94(6) was substituted by the Asylum and Immigration (Treatment of Claimants, etc.) Act 2004 (c.19), section 27(6).back

[2] 
Bangladesh was added by order (the Asylum (Designated States) (No.2) Order 2003 (S.I. 2003/1919)) made under the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (c.41), section 94(5).back

title: Part II
text:
Part IIStrategic Priority – Protecting the countryside and natural resource protection
15. Strategic Outcome: Access to the natural environment
More and better access to the natural environment for recreation, especially
for those who find it difficult to enjoy the health and well-being benefits
that access to nature can bring.
Why it is important that we invest in evidence and innovation (E&I) in this
Strategic Outcome area
Rationale
15.1 People make over 1 billion visits to the English countryside every year and enjoy a wide range
of recreational opportunities, including access to land which traditionally has been free at the
1
point of use. The visits generate spend in the region of £9.7 billion. The health and well-
being benefits of accessing the natural environment are increasingly recognised. Walking and
other forms of recreation in the natural environment can play a significant part in raising
individuals’ levels of physical activity, with the health benefits this can bring. Recent emphasis
on access as an important policy area in its own right means that we need to take a more
strategic approach than before towards understanding how best to achieve policy goals. We
need to bring together disparate sets of evidence which are spread between different
departments and delivery bodies to ensure that this very cross-cutting policy issue is addressed
efficiently in support of clear policy goals.
15.2 The public sector plays a crucial role in the provision, management and regulation of the
infrastructure, and financial support for land managers is increasingly oriented towards
providing public benefits such as a high-quality, accessible countryside. We need evidence to
understand the trends in demand for access, to understand competing demands and the
likely effects these will have, and to continue to develop the most effective ways of
channelling limited public resources to gain maximum benefits. 
15.3 People need to know where they can go and what they can do when they get there.
Although there are guide books, there is also clear evidence of market failures. Information
is patchy and has to be culled from a wide variety of sources, many of them local and many
of them not on the internet. Improving the flow of information can reduce conflict between
visitors and land managers and give people a better understanding of agriculture and the
countryside, thereby helping to break down barriers between town and country. Encouraging
more visitors also increases the value for money of the public investment by generating health
and social benefits as well as more income for rural areas. We need to understand what
information is needed and the most innovative and cost-effective ways of delivering it.
15.4 Some groups of people visit the countryside less often than others, or not at all. People from
black and ethnic-minority communities are two-three times less likely to visit the countryside
2
than white people. Other groups with low rates of use, e.g. those living in disadvantaged
urban areas, could benefit greatly from opportunities to enjoy the natural environment. The
public sector can take action to remove barriers and facilitate use, but we need clear evidence
of how best to do this. 
1
GB Day Visits Survey 2002-03.
2
GB Day Visits Survey 2002-03.
97Part II: Evidence and Innovation needs by Strategic Outcome and related policy areas
Future policy developments
15.5 Increased availability of leisure time is likely to increase demand for access. Increased demand
will also follow from more people becoming more aware of the opportunities available. There
may be changing demand for different types of activity. Climate change will also have an
impact and we need to be able to anticipate where and how this is likely to occur so that we
can plan for it.
15.6 Improved understanding of the long-term health benefits of physical activity for the
prevention of coronary heart disease, some forms of cancer, obesity and associated illnesses
such as diabetes will encourage people to want to take exercise in the natural environment
and brings the potential for increased public funding. The reform of the CAP will allow the
funding of land managers to provide public benefits including access. Sustainability concerns
and the development of sustainable communities will highlight the importance of providing
opportunities for access close to where people live. Again, we need better evidence of how
this may change patterns of use, so we can future-proof policy decisions that are likely to be
taken relatively soon.  
Key policy outcomes
15.7 There are three key policy outcomes for access to the natural environment:
a. Continuing to maintain and renew the infrastructure. Defra is on course to complete the
opening of access to mountain, moor, heath, down and registered common land across
England before the end of 2005. We will next address the issue of improved access to the
coast. We are implementing the rights of way provisions provided for in the Countryside and
Rights of Way Act 2000 and the Countryside Agency (CA) is pursuing the ‘Discovering Lost
Ways’ project which aims to discover unrecorded rights of way and add them to the definitive
map. A new National Park has been created in the New Forest and one in the South Downs is
still under consideration. 
b. Developing and implementing a communications strategy, including information on
recreational opportunities and communication with user groups, landowning interests, and the
commercial sector. We need to ensure that it becomes easier for people to find out what they
can do and where they can go. We will seek to enhance and bring together the material
available on the internet in one site or linked sites.
c. Ensure everyone is given good opportunities to enjoy the natural environment. Defra’s five-year
strategy commits us to completing the Rural White Paper Diversity Review and to supporting
further interdepartmental work on the Public Health White Paper to promote physical activity.
98Strategic Priority – Protecting the countryside and natural resource protection
The role of Defra and other organisations
15.8 Defra has a core responsibility for developing the policy but works with a range of delivery
bodies to apply it in the most advantageous way. The Confederation partners coming
together to create Natural England have relevant expertise and an important role in delivery,
as do the Forestry Commission, the National Parks and Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty
(AONBs) and, in relation to access to water, the Environment Agency and British Waterways. 
15.9 Defra has a strong interest in the policy priorities of Other Government Departments, in
particular: the Department of Health (DH) (Health White Paper including physical activity
delivery plan); the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister (ODPM) (planning policy and
development of better managed urban green space); the Department for Transport (DfT)
(linear access routes including incorporation of rights of way improvement plans in local
transport plans); the Department for Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) (sport and recreation
on land and water and priorities for lottery funding); and the Department for Education and
Skills (DfES) (outdoor learning programmes, including visits to the countryside). We seek to
influence the priorities of these departments both in terms of advancing the direction of 
our own policies and lessening any adverse impacts of theirs on the outcomes we are trying
to secure.
What we have done previously to establish our E&I needs 
15.10 Defra currently has no major in-house programmes of E&I work aligned with these policy
outcomes. Research has generally been led by the Countryside Agency, which has various
programmes in place. A list of them can be found in the detailed Statement of Needs for
this Strategic Outcome, which can be accessed at http://www.defra.gov.uk/wildlife-
countryside/index.htm.
Summary of why the identified E&I needs are required to deliver the Strategic Outcome
15.11 There is a lack of a robust evidence base with which to inform Defra policy and that of Other
Government Departments. Current evidence is piecemeal, has not been developed
specifically in relation to Defra policies, and is owned by a variety of organisations. We need
to draw the evidence together to underpin Defra policy, to tie it in with other Defra evidence
bases such as the Rural Evidence Hub and to use it to influence the development of policies
across Government. We particularly need to understand trends and drivers more clearly to
inform future policy. 
99Part II: Evidence and Innovation needs by Strategic Outcome and related policy areas
Graphical summary of evidence and innovation needs
Please refer to Figure 15 overleaf before responding to the consultation questions below.
How should Defra take forward its E&I needs?
Q.15.i Do you feel there are missing areas of evidence and innovation? Are there key areas of
uncertainty or other opportunities for innovation? Do you feel we have mistakenly
identified any areas of need by developing lines of argument which are untested or
untenable?
Q.15.ii Have we correctly identified the emphasis of investment in evidence and innovation (you
may wish to look at the detailed Statement of Needs at [http://www.defra.gov.uk/wildlife-
countryside/index.htm])? Where should the emphasis of evidence and innovation
investment by Defra be put?
Q.15.iii How should we approach gaps where Defra has no current mechanism or intelligent
customer capability (e.g. policy piloting; social science capability)?
Q.15.iv Where are there opportunities for greater co-ordination/collaboration/partnership with
others to share and develop evidence? Where does this work best at the moment, and
where are the best examples that we should look to?
Q.15.v Are there specific E&I needs relating to access to the natural environment that should be
addressed as a matter of priority? Please list up to a maximum of 10 E&I needs.
Q.15.vi Do you have any other comments on how Defra could improve its Evidence and
Innovation Strategy?
100Strategic Priority – Protecting the countryside and natural resource protection
101

The contribution to the economy of each individual producer, industry or sector is measured using Gross Value Added (GVA) at current basic prices.From 1992 to 2002, the business and financial services sector provided the largest contribution to GVA. In 2002, this industry group accounted for £282.4 billion out of £926.3 billion (30.5 per cent of the total), and the industry itself grew over 11.7 per cent between 2001 and 2002, a faster rate than that of growth in whole economy GVA of 5.1 per cent.Manufacturing industries’ contribution to whole economy GVA passed a key milestone in 1999 by falling below 20 per cent for the first time. In 2002 the contribution of the manufacturing industries stood at only 15.9 per cent. This was a contribution of £147.5 billion, 2.5 per cent down on 2001.The agriculture industries' contribution in 2001 fell below 1.0 per cent for the first time. The creative sector contributed 8.7 per cent of whole economy GVA. Wholesale and retail trades contributed £146.5 billion, growing by 4.8 per cent over 2001.In 2002, the contribution of Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) to whole economy GVA at current basic prices accounted for £61.8 billion (6.7 per cent) of the total.Household spending on all food sector products stood at £160.3 billion in 2002, up 61.5 per cent between 1992 and 2002, whereas spending on catering products consumed outside the home grew by 85.0 per cent. 			October 2003

			Garry Otton Wants to Go Naked in the Sun
			

			
				
				Version: Full article
				
				
						
			

						
			
			The opposition of civil rights for all couples by religionists, Gough goes naked and gay 'handouts'. 

			

			
			
			9 August – 20 September 2003

  

 Scottish Media Monitor

 

  

 What a lovely summer it’s been in Scotland. In England too. Walking through a quiet, sunny meadow skirting a river by Chew Magna in England with the boyf, I was caught playing face invaders by a local parishioner who had stolen up behind us. (I always snog with my eyes shut). As she hurried by, cutting through the grass to the other side of the meadow, I called after her that this being middle-England and all that, I should have been more careful. “You could have been a Daily Mail reader!” I added, trying to make a joke of it. It was a Claude Monet/Laura Ashley moment. Stopping to look over her shoulder she cut the summer frock, straw hat and buttercup afternoon with her steely voice: “The Daily Mail? I wouldn’t wipe my arse with it!” 

  

 There was a popular kids film in the seventies called Melody. It was about a deep friendship between two schoolboys played by Jack Wilde and Mark Lester. Filled with sexual tension, the boy’s friendship was challenged by the growing attraction Mark Lester held towards a schoolgirl called Melody. The subtitle of the film was How Old Is Old Enough? And who knows? Certainly not Scotland’s morally conservative columnists squealing their manufactured outrage in Scotland’s media. Channel 4’s brilliant and compelling season of programmes on teen sexuality included Age Of Consent which put the case for a new age of consent to be set at 14. The Daily Record passed out. “Outrage over TV teen sex series”, hollered reporter Cara Page. So-called “family groups” were dragged in to give voice to the ‘concern’. The partisan Family and Youth Concern produce it by the bucketload. Children’s charity NCH Scotland added: “Greater efforts are needed to promote sex in the context of caring relationships”, which was interesting, since that was the first time in The Record I saw “promoting” and “sex” together in the same sentence. And why not, I ask? The tabloid poured its moral fervour into a leader: “As a ploy to increase their ratings, it makes the gutter a lofty height which Channel 4 can only aspire to”. Humph! The gutter is something The Record would know all about. Then they unleashed their crazy agony aunt, Old Mother (Joan) Burnie onto C4 chiefs. Beside an inspiring picture of a couple of semi-naked teens getting down to it, Old Mother Burnie exploded by the caption: “SHOCKING. Lowering the age of consent would give a green light to paedophiles”. Her argument was filled with contradictions. “Anyone who fondly believes that every teenager waits until they turn 16 before having sex no doubt believes there are fairies in the garden…” In that case, what use was an age of consent at 16 that criminalised kids and debilitated sexual advisors who tried to reach them? After admitting “the law that considers them to be too young at 15, 14, 13 and even younger certainly won’t stop them”, she grumbled disapprovingly: “…With every last breath in my body or word in my computer, I would fight against any lowering of the current age of consent. I could even argue that it should be increased”. Very useful, I’m sure! Having decided that for stopping kids having sex, the age of consent was as much use as a chocolate coil, Burnie insisted kids “need our protection and, fragile though it may be, keeping the legal age of consent as it is provides it”. But with Scotland’s record-breaking level of teenage pregnancies, fragile is no good. Fragile is wearing a condom lubricated with Vaseline. There’ll be tears. Kids explore sex in a variety of different ways, and some don’t explore it at all. Throwing some clumsy barbed-wire fence across their path – which is what the age of consent is – will only cause injury. Advice delivered from a liver-spotted hand, tapping away on a Remington DeLuxe is no good either. (Call Anna Raeburn someone)! The only one to benefit from all this, was, of course, The Daily Record. It sells papers on the back of headlines like: “TEEN PERV IS GUILTY”. This headlined a story of an 18-year-old who “was found guilty of molesting a 14-year-old girl in a fisherman’s hut”. The lad “admitted lewd, indecent and libidinous practices and behaviour towards the girl… in Grantown-on-Spey”. That should help them both on their way to a well-adjusted sex life! And headlines like “GIRL, 14, RUNS OFF WITH TEEN LOVE”. He was 17. But hey! The age of consent was never about protecting children anyway. It is legislation with its roots in a time when a daughter was the property of her father. It was about his right to seek retribution for the vandalism of his property. Her! It works in much the same way today. Only now, both girls and boys under the age of 16 are not considered old enough to consent to sex. Parents are the custodians of that law. If a girl of 15, for example has sex with a boy of 21, the parents could effectively have the young man imprisoned and placed on the sex offender’s register. The age of consent in the Netherlands is 12. That does not mean a child is automatically fair game for any older person to have sex with. It simply takes some of the rights of parents and bestows it on the young person. An independent panel can assess whether criminal action is justified after listening to them. In Switzerland, yet another country with a better record for protecting kids than Scotland has an age of consent that allows for sexual exploration providing the difference in ages is not too great. Scotland’s conservative columnists fell over themselves to bad-mouth sex, especially if ‘children’ demonstrated any taste for it. Linda Watson-Brown, the anti-porn feminist, fresh from The Scottish Daily Mail netted anyone towing her Just Say No line for the otherwise sexually liberal Sunday Herald. After Rod Liddle’s piece in The Spectator on the penalties to be imposed on transgressors under and over the age of 16 who have sex with each other in the new Sexual Offences Bill (currently at committee stage in Westminster), Mrs Katie Grant (another Scottish Daily Mail regular) snorted from her upper class high ground in The Scotsman: “… A trip on to a housing estate in Glasgow or into the High Court would soon show him that while sex may be ‘staggeringly harmless’ for those whose lives are set on an upward trajectory, for those locked in circumstances and rotten education into the downward spiral, underage sex results in dismal pregnancies, disease and the end of any hope of redemption”. Well, you couldn’t get more of a downward spiral than the Peckham estate I was dragged up on, so I know she’s talking shite! Could it simply be that providing better education, greater responsibilities and trust contributes to the Netherlands’ low rate of teenage pregnancies? The Herald was hot on The Record’s heels with its report: “Battle to cut city’s teenage pregnancies”. Glasgow was appointing Scotland’s “first teenage pregnancy czar” following a report showing that one in 10 teenage mothers in Glasgow was under the age of 16. (The figure is even higher in Dundee). This report – as reports on sexuality (particularly gay sexuality) usually do – attracted the usual morally restricting comments from ‘family values’ campaigners. Religionist Peter Kearney for the Catholics perpetuated the lie that “high-profile contraception campaigns had not worked”. (A bit rich considering his own church have consistently objected and seriously undermined any such campaigns). Scotland has never had comprehensive, liberal sex education in its schools! The Catholic Church supports chastity. This is not practical advice for teenagers: it is ideology. Despite mounting empirical data showing that chastity-based sex education hasn’t worked in the USA, schools promoting it there continue to benefit from multi-million dollar government handouts. If they don’t, they risk having funds withheld. Studies show that kids taught ‘abstinence-based sexuality education’ - to give chastity its cuddlier moniker – do not maintain chastity. And, when they have sex, are more likely to indulge in unsafe sex. So tell me? What the hell does the Scottish Executive think it’s doing inviting Catholics to participate in committees discussing sex? As a measure of Catholic backward thinking on sexual issues, Glasgow’s archbishop Mario Conti has called on Catholic politicians to vote against measures awarding same-sex couples equal rights. With atrophied balls dangling under his frock, their absent-minded leader insists gays are ‘evil’ and our unions not able to contribute in a proper way to the procreation and survival of the human race. Since so many gays have kids, I have to take issue with the Pope here and lend my support to celibate priests and Popes who choose not to procreate. They are not evil! The religionist’s martyr and moral campaigner Jim ‘call me Mary Whitehouse’ Coleman, depute leader of Glasgow’s council, which was jointly funding the appointment of a “pregnancy czar” with the NHS added in The Herald: “There will be widespread consultation on the role of the proposed co-ordinator, including parents, schools, the voluntary sector and the wider family network”. Oh, quick! Get the Christian Institute on the phone now!

  

 Now I know I have a bit of a reputation for sticking my boot so far up religionist’s backsides, if you stuck a toothbrush on the end they could clean their teeth. So why stop now. I’ve nothing against the spiritual side of religion. It’s when they organise themselves and appoint a hierarchy the trouble starts. Touchy-feely posters, including a picture of someone of mixed race are advertising the ‘Alpha Course’ all over Scotland. The billboards hide a poisonous message from these evangelicals no better than Keep the Clause. It is a carrot on a desperate stick to fill our empty churches. Their discriminatory message lurks everywhere, including The Ayrshire Post, where it wore the drag of a real news story. “Is it possible to learn about the Christian faith and have fun at the same time? The answer is a resounding ‘yes’ on the Alpha programme, where laughter and fun are key elements”, read the ‘report’, which recommended pre-booking and gave a number to call. 

  

 Ever with its finger in the hymn book, The Herald was strangely drawn to the latest comings and (mostly) goings of the Kirk. The Right Rev Professor Iain Torrance, the Moderator of the Church of Scotland was confronting fellow religionists in the Highlands over gay clergy. (Like anyone gives a fuck)! Well, Rev Ivor MacDonald certainly did. The minister of Kilmuir and Stenscholl told The Herald: “I would want to be satisfied that Professor Torrance regards homosexuality as a sin, and that there is recovery for the homosexual”. Disgracefully, there are no laws in Scotland that would ensure that dangerous Neanderthals like Macdonald aren’t forced to spend time at Her Majesty’s Service sewing postbags for spouting such dangerous language. Call the cloaked crusader to the rescue; enter the Right Reverend Iain Torrance! He said: “I believe that the members of the presbytery of Lochcarron and Skye are utterly sincere in their beliefs and faithful in their intentions. I am not prepared to respond by saying something which will deface them, or polarise the situation further”. In other words: ‘Stick with me; keep the crumbling Church together and you can go on beating up as many queers as you like’! I was up in darkest Lochcarron for Hogmanay this year. Just me, and goodness knows how many other gay men from the Gay Outdoor Club. Staggering back after a night out and a few jars of the devil’s nectar, I will always remember passing this rusty old galvanised tin-shed of a church at the side of the road. Let’s face it. This is the real state of the Church in Scotland today. Rotten, rusty, and like its arguments on gays, full of holes. In the Kirk’s Life and Work magazine, Professor Torrance claims he is “untroubled by the ordination of a person of self-disclosed homosexual orientation who lives a chaste and disciplined life”. What kind of a repressed, fucked-up and distorted discipline is that? Forsaking the quality of close, healthy, loving, sexual relationships for a lifetime of repressed fantasies screwing choirboys, asphyxiating in stockings and suspenders and nights alone with your five-fingered friend! Torrance adds: “There is a difference between an open homosexual in the sense of someone who is graciously allowed by society and the church to say ‘This is how I am. I have different awarenesses and gifts, and I put them at the service of God and the Church’, and someone who is open in the sense of engaging in practice”. Torrance is no better than Gary Wilson, the Dunvegan minister and moderator of the presbytery of Skye and Lochcarron who was reported bleating in The Herald: “I am not homophobic. I am not against homosexuals… What we are saying today is we love the sinners. But we cannot compromise because you have to repent… Homosexuality is a sin. Adultery is a sin. Drunkenness is a sin. But we can recover”. We know this shite damages people. So why aren’t the legislators legislating against it? Remember the Scottish Parliament’s commitment to equality? After Westminster signalled their intention to let gays marry, brave wee Patrick Harvie, the gay Glasgow list MSP for the Greens, championed the rights of ‘straight’ couples to share those rights in Scottish legislation. So what did the Scottish Executive do? Running scared of religionists, they handed over responsibility for legislation to England! Justice minister Cathy Jamieson alluded to the “difficult” period of repealing Section 28 in Scotland, telling The Sunday Herald: “I don’t think anyone would wish to return to what happened then at this stage”. So much for Labour’s mealy-mouthed commitment to a New Scotland! Do remember all this come the next election, won’t you?

  

 The Scottish Daily Mail’s reporter Eddie Barnes exhibited his nasty work under the headline: “Gay marriages plan back on the agenda”. Never mind that it was, in fact, civil registration that would award important benefits in matters of property, inheritance tax, pensions and next of kin. A picture of a giggling couple of men showing off their rings accompanied the ‘report’ which made equality something of an inconvenience, delaying and preventing the Executive getting on with more serious stuff. “First Minister Jack McConnell has made it clear he wants to focus on priorities such as crime and the economy and he will be unwilling to allow such a row to take the spotlight off his plans. It is thought he may push the plans into the long grass today…” Colin Hart of the notorious and militant Christian Institute blasted: “What this would do is put gay couples on a higher status than the relationship between ordinary families. It is only from a husband and wife where you get inheritance rights, and it should stay that way”.

  

 Was this really a story? Brendan Mcginty in The Sunday Mail found Felice Di Resta, 74, a “pensioner behind Scotland’s biggest sex-for-sale sauna wants to open a children’s nursery”. So…? Prudish Mcginty insisted: “Felice’s interest in the nursery is another attempt to look like a respectable businessman – despite the family’s secret business being exposed in the Sunday Mail earlier this year”. This “bizarre double life”, as the easily shocked fish wrapping described Mr Di Resta, referred to him running a “family” café in Whitburn, West Lothian. Disappointingly, The Mail discovered there had been no objections made to West Lothian Council for his plans to convert an old building into a nursery but hung around the street corners long enough to find one of those people who prefer not see their name alongside small-minded tittle-tattle: “For long enough nobody knew they were behind the sauna in Edinburgh but now that’s out in the open, you would think they would try to keep a lower profile. Everybody thought they were respectable and they had been well regarded for just running the Cross café. They kept quiet about their sauna and lapdancing bar. This is a quiet place and it did come as a shock. I wouldn’t want to send my kids to his nursery and there will be plenty of people who agree with me”. Don’t tell me… Her name’s Vera, she has a fag dangling from her bottom lip and she wears rollers under her headscarf!

  

 Steve Gough’s brave attempt to walk naked from Lands End to John o’Groats was especially revealing. He has been arrested more than eight times, attacked by thugs who broke his nose (they were not arrested by the way) and, once in the hands of Lothian and Borders police, was committed to a psychiatric hospital for observation! His refusal to put on something decent resulted in seven days spent in solitary confinement in the cells of Inverness Sheriff Court and resulted in an appearance in front of the Sheriff for an alleged breach of the peace. But whose peace are we talking about here? A lady in Perth, so bothered by Mr Gough’s swinging tackle, couldn’t turn the brass dial of her antique telephone quick enough to call the moral police. Gough was the “English eccentric” (Scotland on Sunday) who had given Scotland a “rude awakening” (The Scottish Daily Mail). But who was standing up for Steve? Not Margaret Denny, the 65-year-old regional representative of British Naturists who gave him a frosty reception when she told Susan Flockhart in The Sunday Herald: “Stephen Gough is a crank, not a true naturist. He only wants to show off his body”. Gough made a useful political statement, challenging the reason we wear clothes. Surely, to keep warm? We seem to have acquired a few accessories along the way, like the promotion of fashion and ‘hiding our shame’. Old Mother (Joan) Burnie tried to insist in The Daily Record it was about protecting ourselves from the excesses of the sun. Even if that could be argued in Scotland, her claim that this is achieved by wrapping ourselves in light cotton is nonsense. Since when did light cotton give full protection against sunburn? Jeremy Watson in Scotland on Sunday found some protection in the Edinburgh haar (mist): “How lucky we are that climes are cooler north of the Border”, he sighed, before adding: “My advice, should you encounter him, is to keep your eyes fixed on his straggly beard and wish him bon voyage”. But perhaps the ice was, after all, melting. A normally frigid Mrs Katie Grant asked in The Scotsman: “Why are we so exercised by this true British eccentric?” The truth is, Gough is just the tip of a melting iceberg. While a number of gays have expressed their desire to join his protest, more of them were quietly stripping off on gay beaches in Scotland this unusually hot summer, and, along many of Scotland’s other beaches, more women were copying their European cousins, flouting the laws of decency and daring to remove their tops. I doubt if Steve Gough will take much comfort from the abolishment of the 19th century law of ‘shameless indecency’ (a notifiable offence under the 1997 Sex Offenders Act) by the Court of Appeal in Edinburgh. It has been recommended that it should be replaced by an act that makes it an offence to offend ‘public indecency’. Steve Gough is scheduled to appear at Inverness Sheriff Court on 7 January 2004. I’ve no doubt his shamelessly decent tackle will be properly covered by Scotland’s media. 

  

 If a lone man wandering around naked stirred horrible fears in the current climate of paedosteria, then Elaine Ross from Arbroath’s appearance in Perth Sheriff Court, actively seeking strange men for sex only added to it. The Daily Record gasped: “SEX CHAT ACCUSED ‘WALKED AROUND IN NUDE’.” Ooh, missus! Ross was “confronted” by “a visitor”, Norma Mackenzie to her home who was “shocked by her nudity”. She saw “scantily clad snaps” of Ross who told her she had used “sex chatlines”. Her court appearance had her crossing the moral boundaries when children told how “they had seen a man get into bed with the accused”. The report revealed: “Ross, 42, is alleged to have exposed four children to moral danger by talking explicitly on a chatline while they were present. She is also alleged to have taken photos of a child with a nearly naked woman and left other graphic pictures of herself lying in open view”. Via a video link, The Daily Record reported how the seven-year-old told the court how Ross had talked about “rude things about a man and a lady. Things they were doing. Together. S-E-X”.

  

 Endemol, the production company behind Big Brother, are the people behind BBC 2’s Restoration programme. Twice weekly they paraded a selection of properties that were in need of some tender loving care. That’s where we came in, registering our vote to hopefully send a fat cheque winging its way to rescue the rotting rafters of your choice. All very worthy. After a researcher read my feature on Kinloch Castle on the Hebridean island of Rhum, someone was despatched to get my take on its sexual history. This lavish Edwardian baronial pile was the home of gay George Bullough a man who was responsible for turning it into, well…. a pretty plush brothel that hosted the wildest of orgies. Royalty attended. Not only did Bullough, a enthusiastic writer of erotic fiction, recruit his own team of handsome young men for some occasional footie, but his staff were promised a bit extra in their wages if they wore a kilt. Bullough was an expensive queen. (Just imagine spending £20m in today’s money on a holiday home). He had to have the latest and the best. The giant Imhof and Mukle Orchestrion rang out over the whole island from where it sat under the stairs. The Edwardian showers were delightful, tantalisingly spraying water into every orifice. But whilst the silk brocades, the fabulous paintings and elaborate furniture remained intact, the S&M cage was politely returned to the family. And his parties…? Well, if walls could talk! I eagerly watched Griff Rhys-Jones take viewers round, waiting for this important monument to our sexual history to be uncovered, but the nearest we got was a discreet mention of “lavish dinner parties” and “wild soirees”. In Edwardian times, while the working classes would be exposed and castigated for any lapse in morality, the upper classes quietly got away with murder. No change there then! There secret was safe. Thank goodness for writer Lucinda Lambton who managed, when Kinloch Castle made into the top 10, to refer to the 214 jets of water from the elaborate Victorian showers, especially the one coming up “like a ramrod up your privates”. 

  

 Helen Martin’s a jolly old sausage, isn’t she? She couldn’t wait to tell Edinburgh’s Evening News that she “supported Scotland’s gay community over the recent gay pride march through Edinburgh”. Good for you, love! (But who the fuck is Helen Martin when she’s at home)? Before we’d finished sweeping up the empty bottles of Chardonnay and checked that the lesbian who’d had her jaw smashed by a straight guy outside a gay bar was OK, dear Ms Martin was submitting her piece to the Evening News for publication. “Treating them (gays) as some kind of special minority deserving of lavish hand-outs is wrong”. Apparently, (yawn), “crackpot grants” and (zzzzzzz) “lavish handouts” were once again being thrown at gays. Ms Martin was peeved that a “preposterous” £39,500 from the Heritage Lottery Fund had been allocated for a gay heritage trail around Manchester. “Personally, I have nothing against a gay heritage trail…” she opined. But with dead straights a more worthy cause than living gays, she was horrified at the “very dubious decisions” that led to “a request by veterans of one of the bloodiest battles of the Second World War, for a mere £12,500, half the cost of a trip to pay their final respects to the 20,000 who died during the fighting in Monte Cassino” being turned down. Ms Martin tried to weigh up gay causes against more “worthy” heterosexual ones. “If our natural history and literary past isn’t worthy of a leg up, why should a mosaic of Quentin Crisp and a former print shop – now a general memorabilia store – where gay pamphlets were once churned out, be any different?” Have a quick look round at collection boxes on shop counters next time you’re out shopping, will you? Pretty little tins and boxes sit there for all those more “worthy” causes: Abused kids, cancer, pet rescue and crumbling church roofs. Now find the collecting tin for people living with HIV or AIDS on the nicely polished oak counter of your friendly bank. The Lottery Fund was not established to give priority to popular causes approved by Ms Helen Martin. Our history is also important. Gays are particularly careless with it. It is very welcome that there is someone out there intelligent enough to recognise this. Tiring of one line of homophobia Ms Martin pretends her back is against the wall. What do gays “actually want from us”? She cries. Adding “their strongest desire should be to be treated the same way as everyone else. It seems to me that instead, they want to maintain their alienation and difference. They want to continually remind society that they are a breed apart – and in this regard at least – a charity case. The rest of us have nothing to reproach ourselves for and no duty to pay up”. Before warning the gay community to “grow up and start pulling their weight”, she weighed us up against “women, Jews, Catholics” and “many other communities”, (if you mean people of colour, dear, please say so), who she was emphatic were “equally or more a part of Britain’s heritage”. (More a part)? And as for that Pride march she enjoyed so much: “Alas they sold us short with a dull, old, trade union-style, placard-waving trudge through the city rather than the entertaining spectacle of costume, music and dance enjoyed in other cities”. Well, well, Ms Martin. Such an enthusiastic supporter of Pride as yourself will no doubt be wanting to dip into your shooting jacket pocket to cough up some hard earned cash or whatever else Edinburgh’s Evening News paid you for this nasty little homophobic rant for some floats next year?

  

 How inspired our gay ‘friend’ must have been by The Sunday Times Scotland’s health correspondent, Sue Leonard’s piece, snorting at “£1m spent on Scotland’s first gay health centre”. Leonard decided, “the centre has raised concerns that public money is being spent on a minority group which already has access to NHS health provision”. (This is Edinburgh, by the way. And it doesn’t even have an LGBT community centre)! It was that damnable lottery again; giving away good money to unfashionable causes that hadn’t a chance in hell of getting money off more ‘respectable’ bodies as Margaret Davidson, chief executive of the Scotland Patients’ Association advised when she told the paper: “I do not think it is a good idea to spend NHS money on one specific group of people; it has to be for every patient”. Which hardly represents much of saving if you have to spend more money teaching clinicians who haven’t a Scooby what gay boys do under the sheets, or why a lesbian won’t go to their local GP. Any health centre, if it is used, will offer benefits and savings through preventative and precautionary measures. A full surgery is a full surgery. And with this one, I suspect the donated copies of ScotsGay, Gay Times and Attitude in the waiting room we be well thumbed. Healthy living centres were designed to target disadvantage communities and this was the first time the New Opportunities Fund had given any money to gays. There has never been any reliable estimate of how many queers there are in Scotland, but what the hell; Ms Leonard was on a roll. “There are an estimated 500,000 lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender people living in Scotland”. (Y’r arse, lady)! The Sunday Times Scotland fielded comments from, (surprise, surprise), militant religionists and known homophobes. John Deighan of the Catholic Church was reported saying. “NHS money should be promoting healthy living. We know there are health risks associated with homosexual lifestyles. It seems to be that homosexuals are being given extra special attention compared to the rest of the population”. If the poisonous opinion of the Catholic Church is at all relevant to gay issues, then our opinions should be sought on all newspaper reports involving Catholics. (Bags all the ones about paedophile priests and twisted nuns)! David Davidson, the Scottish Tory health spokesperson warned: “They (I think he means people like me) will have the same problems as everyone else. They should be dealt with in the normal way. I do not see why they should have a parallel health service. I do not see that as a good value for money exercise at a time when NHS capacity is under pressure”. The Tories would know all about that, withholding essential safer sex information from the very people who needed it when the country first came to terms with the HIV/AIDS crisis. 

  

 The Sunday Mail’s Chris Mcauley got pissed on the cheap communal wine before pissing on the lesbians. Mannotincluded.com offers a useful service to women who wish to become pregnant. After a good deal of care, cost and counselling, Mannotincluded.com come up with the white stuff. Mcauley didn’t get it. His too churchy report seemed more concerned how a “Glasgow-based courier firm Citysprint delivered the DIY baby kits to their door within an hour of the order being placed”. (A hot delivery by a cute motorcyclist? Now that’s what I call service)! Of course the Church were going to be “outraged”, so what was the point of this story if not to chew the cud of their moral drivel on the front page. The Kirk choked: “People in gay relationships need to look at the responsibilities they have and ask themselves if this pizza delivery service is the way to begin”. And the Kirk needs to ask why lesbians can’t subscribe to the same services offered to heterosexuals before it opens its gob. And so too does Peter Kearney, spokesman for the Catholic Church who pointed to the “potentially enormous risks to the health of women receiving the sperm”. The Internet firm was described as being “exempt from strict medical scrutiny” and used “a legal loophole” to escape licensing. In fact, both women and semen were carefully screened. Women were offered more protection than they could ever hope for from any old Joe Blow they might’ve picked up for less money in The Dog and Duck. This service doesn’t cum cheap! Kearney used children to drive home his dubious moral point. “…The most important issue is the welfare of children who might be conceived and especially their mental and emotional welfare. This rides roughshod over their future”. Catholicism and children. Can I just mention Smyllum Park orphanage here? Frank Hurley reminded us in Scotland on Sunday: “The Catholic nuns who ran the institution until it shut in the 1980s already stand accused of terrorising the living in their care. Now it has been revealed how children who died during Smyllum’s century in existence were placed without ceremony in pauper’s graves at nearby St Mary’s and no record kept of their final resting place”.

  

 I wonder whose devilishly conceived idea it was to invite Conservative, Catholic Mrs Katie Grant, regular columnist in the religionist’s Scottish Daily Mail to be a panellist at the Edinburgh Television Festival to discuss the Broadcasting Standards Commission’s change to Ofcom. In her column in The Scotsman she explained: “I was asked what should and what should not appear on our screens. This involved being given a badge at reception labelling me ‘Tasteless and Indecent’, the provocative name given to our debate”. Poor dear. Looking around in amazement at the television execs she found a “cultivated air of world-weary dishevelment (older men), or tight black trousers displaying neat bottoms (younger women, or were they men too – it was difficult to tell…)”. She watched clips from “the most controversial programmes of the year”. She thought. Everything from: “Celebrity Wheelchair Challenge to the gay kiss on The Bill, Designer Vaginas (made my eyes water), the prolonged homoerotic scene in Queer as Folk, a man’s death rattle and the use of a stallion ejaculating to make people laugh in 100 Things To Do Before You Die”. Given her strong connections with horses, she most disliked the latter. But then, in her My Little Pony view of life, I suspect homosexuals and horses shouldn’t be having sex. She was once again ruffled “when a picture of Mary Whitehouse appeared on the screen” and “all the TV executives rocked with laughter”. Mrs Grant argued for a heightening of good standards on TV: Her standards. “Coming soon to your sitting room will be the nude full-frontal male erection. It’s the latest thing, darling, and if you don’t like it, there is obviously something wrong with you”. No darling. There’s something just below the picture called an ‘off’ switch. Use it!

  

 Garry Otton’s book SEXUAL FASCISM is published by Ganymede Books priced £8.99.

  

 garry@scottishmediamonitor.com

   

 CUT IT OUT…

  

 Brian McNair in Scotland on Sunday on the US Episcopal Church’s decision to ordain an openly gay bishop for New Hampshire: “When it declares by its actions that homophobia is no longer to be viewed as a divinely ordained religious duty, and that gay men and women can share not just a pew but an altar with their straight co-believers, its affiliates in the rest of the world listen. Some have threatened to take their ball back and split the church, but the same thing happened when black people were admitted to the senior ranks of the priesthood, and then again when it was the turn of women to be treated as equals under the eyes of God. Such threats didn’t amount to much then, and they won’t now, not least because beggars can’t be choosers. The Anglican Church has only 80 million members worldwide, about as many as worship David Beckham, and can’t afford to alienate the sizeable proportion of those among its flock who are gay”. Nice one, Bri!

  

 That lovely Muriel Gray up to her usual mischief in The Sunday Herald: “Some Catholic spokesperson wrote in a characteristically silly letter to The Herald about the inefficacy of ‘those who would silence the Catholic Church’. You’ve got it all wrong, mate. No-one wants to silence it if this is the stuff it’s coming out with, in fact we want more. Tell us what you really think of women. Give us the low-down on reproductive health in the Third World. The silence is the scary bit. It’s only when we hear loud and clear just how backward and delusional religious fundamentalists are that we can take action to prevent them wielding power. And, by the way, the Leviticus writings that have helped convince the Pope that gay people are evil also helpfully suggests stoning anyone wearing mixed fabrics. Nice cassock, John Paul. Do I detect a sliver of rayon and silk amongst that Egyptian cotton weave?”

  

 Ron Ferguson in The Herald: “Ecclesiastical politics is not for the faint of heart, especially when matters of human sexuality are involved. Too many of the participants believe that God is speaking directly into their ear-piece to make the business peaceable and calm”.

  

 Renowned homophobe and lunatic right-wing columnist Richard Littlejohn whose opinion is fed to Scotland in addition to our own homophobes in national editions of The Sun: “There’s even a gay directory enquiries, operating out of a shed in Windsor. Shouldn’t that be a cottage? You’ll know you’ve got through to that when the operator answers: ‘Hello sailor’.”

  

 Justice minister Cathy Jamieson’s excuses why male rape cannot be recognised in Scotland as it is in England and Wales in Scotland on Sunday: “Non-consensual intercourse with a man can constitute two specific common law crimes: indecent assault and sodomy. Penalties that can be applied to these offences are limited only by the court in which they are heard, and for cases in the High Court that can mean up to life imprisonment. This applies equally to female and male rape. I have no plans to review the definition of rape or other sexual offences. I believe that present common law provisions are flexible and robust enough to deal with rape cases”.

  

 Assistant chief constable Graeme Pearson, secretary of the Association of Chief Police in Scotland’s crime standing committee’s excuses why male rape cannot be recognised in Scotland in Scotland on Sunday: “Where we have had reports of this offence, pursued evidence and there has been a prosecution, that prosecution has been taken very seriously”.

  

 Robert McNeil in The Scotsman on the intelligence of fish and the Countryside Alliance that, along with Brian Souter’s Keep the Clause, chose a PR company led by an ex-editor of Scottish editions of The Sun: “The research has led to hopes that fish society might be compared to the organisation of primate-style groups such as the Countryside Alliance, whose members are similarly thought by most people to be unevolved simpletons with short attention span, but who have also shown early signs of manipulative behaviour patterns, predatory strategies and established hierarchy”.

  

 Comedian Craig Hill in Gay Scotland: “We would look over the Sunday Post letters page and laugh about ridiculous things that people had written. They just didn’t realise how funny they were. It was suggested that I should take my particular view on life on the stage…”

Statutory Instruments printed from this website are printed under the superintendence and authority of the Controller of HMSO being the Queen's Printer of Acts of Parliament.


The legislation contained on this web site is subject to Crown Copyright protection. It may be reproduced free of charge provided that it is reproduced accurately and that the source and copyright status of the material is made evident to users.


It should be noted that the right to reproduce the text of Statutory Instruments does not extend to the Queen's Printer imprints which should be removed from any copies of the Statutory Instrument which are issued or made available to the public. This includes reproduction of the Statutory Instrument on the Internet and on intranet sites. The Royal Arms may be reproduced only where they are an integral part of the original document.






The text of this Internet version of the Statutory Instrument which is published by the Queen's Printer of Acts of Parliament has been prepared to reflect the text as it was Made. A print version is also available and is published by The Stationery Office Limited as the The Occupational Pensions (Revaluation) Order 2001, ISBN 
0 11 038865 8.  The print version may be purchased by clicking  here. Braille copies of this Statutory Instrument can also be purchased at the same price as the print edition by contacting TSO Customer Services on 0870 600 5522 or e-mail:customer.services@tso.co.uk.




Further information about the publication of legislation on this website can be found by referring to the Frequently Asked Questions. 


To ensure fast access over slow connections, large documents have been segmented into "chunks". Where you see a "continue" button at the bottom of the page of text, this indicates that there is another chunk of text available.








STATUTORY INSTRUMENTS



2001 No. 3690


PENSIONS


The Occupational Pensions (Revaluation) Order 2001

	 	
Made	15th November 2001	 
	 	
Laid before Parliament	22nd November 2001	 
	 	
Coming into force	1st January 2002	 




The Secretary of State for Work and Pensions, in exercise of the powers conferred upon him by paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 3 to the Pension Schemes Act 1993[1], hereby makes the following Order:



Citation and commencement

    

1.
 - (1) This Order may be cited as the Occupational Pensions (Revaluation) Order 2001.


    (2) This Order shall come into force on 1st January 2002.



The revaluation percentage for each revaluation period

    

2.
For the purposes of paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 3 to the Pension Schemes Act 1993, the revaluation percentage for each revaluation period specified in column 1 below is the percentage specified in column 2 in relation to that period.

Column 2

Signed by authority of the Secretary of State for Work and Pensions.



Ian McCartney

Minister of State, Department for Work and Pensions



15th November 2001





EXPLANATORY NOTE



(This note is not part of the Order)


This Order is made, as required by paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 3 to the Pension Schemes Act 1993, in the year beginning 1st January 2001 and specifies revaluation percentages for the purpose of the revaluation on or after 1st January 2002 of benefits under occupational pension schemes, as required by section 84 of, and Schedule 3 to, that Act.


This Order does not impose any costs on business.

title: DEFRA, UK: Ministers' speeches: Lord Whitty speech for the Mapping The Countryside Event
text:
DEFRA, UK: Ministers' speeches: Lord Whitty speech for the Mapping The Countryside Event
		 
      SPEECH FOR THE MAPPING THE COUNTRYSIDE EVENT
GIVEN BY LORD WHITTY, MINISTER FOR FOOD AND FARMING


	  31st OCTOBER 2001, ELAND HOUSE

    	 
      

    





    
Good morning ladies and gentlemen. I am very pleased to be able to speak to you today at the launch of Land Cover Map 2000. I am pleased for two main reasons. Firstly, on behalf of the government sponsors of Land Cover Map, to welcome and celebrate the completion of this landmark exercise to map out the broad habitats across the whole of the United Kingdom. And, secondly, from my new Department's perspective, to say a few words about the approach we are taking to build on the strong scientific traditions of the former MAFF and DETR to mobilise environmental information and create a strong evidence base for policy making. 


As many of you will be aware, since the creation of the Department for Environment Food and Rural Affairs last June, we have consulted on our draft aim and objectives. 


I am very grateful for those of you here who have contributed. We have listened to your views and the Department' new aim is:
'Sustainable development, which means a better quality of life for everyone, now and for generations to come, including:

- a better environment at home and internationally, and sustainable use of natural resources;

- economic prosperity through sustainable farming, fisheries, food , water and other industries that meet consumers' requirements; and

- thriving economies and communities in rural areas and a countryside for all to enjoy.'


We know that we have some very big challenges to address in these areas - both very immediate, such as enabling farmers and rural communities to recover in the aftermath of the Foot and Mouth disease, and much longer term such as tackling the global problems of climate change and declining biodiversity. As Science Minister in DEFRA, I intend to assure that the highest standards of science and scientific information are used to shape our policies. We will do this by using the best scientific advice and information, drawn from as many sources as possible. I emphasise the word 'using' because it is not only a matter of collecting scientific data but ensuring that it is 'fit for purpose' and accessible to the user.


The starting point for our policies on sustainable development and a better quality of life must be sound information on the status and trends in natural resources, rural communities and economic prosperity. We need this information to set our objectives, to shape our policy and manage effectively and to measure progress.  Having information about the state of our land - its fields, woods, marshes, moors and mountains - is a fundamental requirement and yet such information is remarkably difficult to come by. It is for this reason that my Department (and formerly both DETR and MAFF) teamed up with the Natural Environment Research Council, the administrations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland and other government agencies to commission Land Cover Map 2000 as part of the Countryside Survey 2000 initiative. 


Land Cover Map 2000 is, I believe, the first ever, national map of land cover and habitats as seen from space, at a detailed field-by-field resolution, anywhere in the world.  I think this is a remarkable achievement and a tribute to the world class science and the dedication shown by the research team at the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology.  And, apart from this hard won technical success, I think it also a very good demonstration of how we, in the newly devolved UK, can work together and with the research community to deliver common goals. I am very pleased that this co-operation is now extending on an exploratory basis to collaboration with the Republic of Ireland under an initiative of the North/South Ministerial Council.  Furthermore, I believe that we will be able to lead the way in Europe by the semi-automated conversion of the UK Land Cover Map 2000 to meet the standards of European Commission's latest CORINE Land Cover Map update. 


I have been fortunate this morning to have had a preview of the Land Cover Map database which you will see this afternoon. Of course, I am not an expert but I was greatly impressed to see  the surroundings of my home at Shaftesbury, Dorset.  I know that the Land Cover Map has many potential applications in my Department alone, for example helping to locate areas of high landscape or biodiversity interest,  assessing impacts of climate change and reporting on the state of the environment.  We will be exploring the exciting new opportunites to combine data from the Land Cover Map with other information about the rural environment to make assessments of the changing countryside character of England. No doubt you will already have many other applications in mind.
 

However, reflecting on my earlier comments about using only the best scientific information, I will be asking my technical advisers to look critically at this new product to ensure it is fully and appropriately exploited within DEFRA. I am sure that you will wish to undertake this sort of evaluation as well. Fortunately the task will be made all the easier by the detailed work that has already been done to compare the quality of the map with ground-based surveys from Countryside Survey 2000.  No doubt you will hear much more about this.  


Collecting data from satellites and turning them into information, as in Land Cover Map 2000, is only part of the story.  For such information to be useful it needs to be accessible. You will see this during the series of demonstrations of information systems that have been arranged for this afternoon.  The advances in Geographical Information Systems and internet technology over the last few years have been quite remarkable. In DEFRA we are at the forefront in the use of these technologies to help us bring information to bear on particular problems and to share our information with others.  For example, throughout the Foot and Mouth Disease outbreak we have published, on our website, an interactive map of constantly updated information on the location of cases and disease control zones. This has been used by the general public, including farmers, to identify restrictions in force at any location, with over 600,000 visits to the website a day being received at the peak of activity. 



The demonstrations will I hope give you a taste of things still to come as we fully embrace this age of e-Government. For those of you who have struggled to collate information about policy initiatives and constraints in rural areas in England, the new project on Multi-Agency Geographical Information for the Countryside will be, as the acronym suggests, just like 'MAGIC'.  Funded by DEFRA and the  Invest to Save Budget, MAGIC aims to provide internet access to  information about countryside designations and schemes such as Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty, Sites of Special Scientific Interest, Countryside Stewardship  agreements and historic monuments. Initially, the information will be shared between the project partners in England - DEFRA, DTLR, the Countryside Agency, English Nature, English Heritage and the Forestry Commission - but I don't see any reason why MAGIC cannot be made publicly available as soon as that is technically feasible.  


And again, the National Biodiversity Network is really ambitious but essential project to create an internet-based one-stop-shop for the information about UK biodiversity, currently held by a large number and great variety of organisations including local authorities, voluntary groups, national collections and government departments and agencies.  A great deal has already been achieved by the National Biodiversity Network Trust by pooling resources and expertise.  My colleague Michael Meacher has on previous occasions strongly endorsed the work of the Trust and DEFRA has so far committed around £0.5 million to support the ongoing development of the Network.  Part of this development work will make it possible to provide free public internet access to some of the Land Cover Map 2000 data through the NBN.


The Countryside Information System is, on the other hand, a comparatively well-established, policy support tool. It was developed in the mid-1990s to provide public access to the results of the Countryside Survey and a wide range of other environmental and administrative datasets using a one kilometre square grid for Great Britain and Northern Ireland.  The demonstration will show how summary information from Land Cover Map 2000 can be used in the Countryside Information System to enable users to calculate land cover and habitat statistics for any area within the UK. 


I am also very pleased that DTLR have arranged for a demonstration of the National Land Use Database. This cross-government partnership project is aiming to develop a complete and consistent geographical record of land use for Great Britain which is kept up to date. It will be built on the new Ordnance Survey polygon-based, large-scale mapping product, MasterMap.  Land use information for each polygon will be obtained from existing data sets, including Land Cover Map 2000 in rural areas.


I can hardly talk about 'Mapping the Countryside' without referring to our plans for implementation of the new right of public access on foot to open countryside provided by the Countryside and Rights of Way Act 2000. We are committed to opening up all access land by 2005. Before the new right of access can be implemented, there must be agreement as to where people can go and the rules they need to follow. The Countryside Agency is charged with preparing statutory maps of open country and common land in England. The Agency must consult on the content of the maps, and landowners will be able to appeal to the Secretary of State before maps are issued in a conclusive form. 


The Countryside Agency are preparing to roll-out the statutory maps of open country and registered common land on a region-by-region basis starting soon with the South East and part of the North West. These areas were chosen as lead mapping areas because they cover the full range of open country land types found in England. This does not necessarily mean regional commencement of the new right. Whether we decide to bring the right into effect regionally will, in part, depend on the results of the mapping in first two regions.


So, I hope you will agree that these examples show, even in these early days, that DEFRA is moving in the right direction. We are committed to developing the scientific evidence base for policy making, to joining-up initiatives across government and working in partnership with others outside government. We will be forward thinking and innovative in our approach, focusing on high quality performance and building on the best practice in the former DETR and MAFF.  We will be outward-facing and inclusive, sharing our information and tools with others, so that we can work collectively towards the achievement of our objectives.


Unfortunately, I will have to leave shortly for another engagement but before I go I would like to commend Land Cover Map 2000 to you and I would like to congratulate the project team on bringing this world-leading work to a conclusion.  I would also like to acknowledge the crucial advisory and financial input of the other consortium members without whom the full UK picture would not have been possible. Finally I would like to pay tribute to the Natural Environment Research Council and the British National Space Centre for having the foresight to invest in the development of the science and technology that was necessary to underpin this very practical application.
DEFRA, UK: Ministers' speeches: Lord Whitty speech for the Mapping The Countryside Event

by Helen Johnstone





A mother was told  she could not use a a photograh of her bare chested baby son for a passport because it was 'offensive' Tracey Barnes for Somerset was told by passport officials  that it would offend reiligious countries....





Will English Ladies need passport pictures wearing a Burka on ? in future.  


We dont want to offend do we ?





Well done the Home Office way to go !

title: Governors
text:
Governors		Print this page   Close 

	
	
	Board of Governors
The Board of Governors of The Wellcome Trust Limited, the corporate trustee of the Wellcome Trust, carries out the charitable objects of the Wellcome Trust as laid out in the Trust's constitution.  Please refer to the Trust policy on 		
		
			
		
	Conflicts of interest, which Governors must comply with.
		
		
			
		
	Dominic Cadbury

Martin Bobrow

Christopher Edwards

Adrian Bird

Jean Thomas

Edward Walker-Arnott

Alastair Ross Goobey

Ronald Plasterk

Peter Smith

Patricia Hodgson


	
	
		
	
	
		
			
			
		
	
	
	
		
		
	
		
		
		
		
	





	Sir Dominic Cadbury (Chairman)
Dominic Cadbury is Chairman of the Wellcome Trust and a Director of Misys. Previously he was Chief Executive and subsequently Chairman of Cadbury Schweppes, where he spent his career. 
He has been involved in many aspects of education through the Confederation of British Industry (CBI) where he was Chairman of its Education and Training Committee and was Deputy Chairman of the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority. He is a Fellow of Eton College, Vice-President of Edgbaston High School for Girls and a Trustee of the Teaching Awards Trust which honours outstanding teachers at an annual Oscar ceremony shown every year on BBC TV. He is Chairman of an advisory committee of the National Life Story Collection of the British Library. He was made Chancellor of Birmingham University in December 2002.

	 	top




	
	
		
	
	
		
			
			
		
	
	
	
		
		
	
		
		
		
		
	





	Professor Martin Bobrow CBE, FRS, FRCP, FRCPath (Deputy Chairman)
Professor Bobrow was appointed Governor in October 1996. He was born in Johannesburg, South Africa, and graduated from the University of Witwatersrand. Professor Bobrow was then Professor of Human Genetics in Amsterdam and Prince Philip Professor of Paediatric Research at Guy's Hospital (UMDS), London. Since 1995 he has been Professor of Medical Genetics at the University of Cambridge, and has an interest in clinical genetics and cytogenetics. He is currently Chairman of ULTRA (Unrelated Living Transplant Regulating Authority) and a member of the Human Genetics Advisory Commission.

	 	top




	
	
		
	
	
		
			
			
		
	
	
	
		
		
	
		
		
		
		
	





	Professor Christopher Edwards MD, FRCP, FRCPEd, FRSE, FMedSci, HonDSc
Professor Edwards became a Governor in 1994, when he was Professor of Clinical Medicine with a special interest in endocrinology, and Dean of the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Edinburgh. From November 1995 to December 2000 he was Principal of the Imperial College School of Medicine. He is currently Vice-Chancellor of the University of Newcastle upon Tyne.

	 	top




	
	
		
	
	
		
			
			
		
	
	
	
		
		
	
		
		
		
		
	





	Professor Adrian Bird FRS, FRSE
Professor Bird became a Governor in October 2000. Since 1999, he has held the Buchanan Chair of Genetics at the University of Edinburgh and is Director of the Wellcome Trust Centre for Cell Biology at the University of Edinburgh. His interests are the structure and function of the mammalian genome, and in particular the role of DNA methylation. He is Editor of Technical Tips Online and a member of the Editorial Boards of Molecular and Cellular Biology and Molecular Cell. Awards include the Louis-Jeantet Prize for Medicine and Gabor Medal of the Royal Society (London), both awarded in 1999. He is also a member of the Scientific Advisory Board of the Rett Syndrome Research Foundation.

	 	top




	
	
		
	
	
		
			
			
		
	
	
	
		
		
	
		
		
		
		
	





	Professor Jean Thomas CBE, ScD, FRS, FMedSci
Professor Thomas became a Governor in October 2000. She has been in Cambridge since 1967, where she is also a Fellow of New Hall. She became Professor of Macromolecular Biochemistry in 1991 and was Director of the Cambridge Centre for Molecular Recognition from 1993 to 2003. Her research interests include the structure and dynamics of chromatin, and the structures and interactions of chromosomal proteins that bend DNA. She was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1986 and became a CBE for services to science in 1993. Professor Thomas is an elected Member of the European Molecular Biology Organisation (EMBO) and of the Academia Europaea, and has served as a Member of the Council and Scientific Advisory Committee of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, the Scientific Advisory Committee of the Lister Institute of Preventative Medicine, as well as a Trustee of the British Museum.

	 	top




	
	
		
	
	
		
			
			
		
	
	
	
		
		
	
		
		
		
		
	





	Edward Walker-Arnott
Mr Walker-Arnott became a Governor in October 2000. He has extensive experience as a commercial lawyer, including banking, insurance, employment, venture capital and intellectual property rights. He has also conducted a number of major litigation cases throughout his professional career, including Guinness plc v Saunders (1990), an important law case which looked at directors' disclosures of interest. Mr Walker-Arnott is currently a consultant for the international law firm Herbert Smith.

	 	top




	
	
		
	
	
		
			
			
		
	
	
	
		
		
	
		
		
		
		
	





	Alastair Ross Goobey CBE
Mr Ross Goobey became a Governor and a member of the Trust's Investment Committee in January 2002. An experienced investment manager, he has been Chief Executive of Hermes Pensions Management Ltd since 1992 and retired from this post at the end of December 2001. Before joining Hermes Pensions Management he was Chief Investment Strategist with James Capel & Company Ltd and has been a Special Adviser to HM Treasury.

	 	top




	
	
		
	
	
		
			
			
		
	
	
	
		
		
	
		
		
		
		
	





	Professor Ronald Plasterk
Professor Plasterk joined the Board of Governors on 1 April 2004. He is Professor of Developmental Genetics at the University of Utrecht in the Netherlands, and Director of the Hubrecht Laboratory. He is a member of the European Molecular Biology Organization (EMBO), the Dutch National Health Council and the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Science.
His research interests are in genetics and the functional genomic studies of C. elegans and zebrafish. He is also a regular columnist for a Dutch newspaper and on Dutch television. In 1999 he was awarded the Spinoza Prize by the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research and, in 2002, the EMBO award for Communication in the Life Sciences.

	 	top




	
	
		
	
	
		
			
			
		
	
	
	
		
		
	
		
		
		
		
	





	Professor Peter Smith CBE
Professor Smith joined the Board of Governors on 1 June 2004. He is Professor of Tropical Epidemiology at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. He is Chair of the Spongiform Encephalopathy Advisory Committee (SEAC; up until July 2004) on which he has served since 1996, for the Department of Health, the Food Standards Agency and the Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs. Since 2003 he has been a member of the Nuffield Council on Bioethics.
Professor Smith gained a first-class honours degree in Applied Mathematics from City University, from where he also has a DSc in Medical Statistics. His research interests include studies on cancers and tropical diseases, vaccine and other intervention studies against malaria, HIV, tuberculosis, hepatitis and leishmaniasis. He is a member of the Partnership Board of the European and Developing Countries Clinical Trials Partnership, a Fellow of the Academy of Medical Sciences and was made a CBE for services to SEAC and to Tropical Disease Research in 2001. He was awarded the Donald Reid Medal for distinguished contributions to epidemiology in 2003.

	 	top





	
	
		
	
	
		
			
			
		
	
	
	
		
		
	
		
		
		
		
	





	Patricia Hodgson DBE
Patricia Hodgson joined the Board of Governors on 1 June 2004. Until the end of 2003, she was Chief Executive of the Independent Television Commission (ITC), which was the regulatory body for commercial television prior to the establishment of Ofcom. 
Prior to joining the ITC in 2000, she was the Main Board Director at the BBC responsible for Policy and Planning, a post she held for eight years. Her early career was spent as a radio and TV producer and journalist.
She is a member of the Committee on Standards in Public Life, a non-executive Director of GWR Group PLC and a non-executive Director of the Competition Commission. 

	 	top
Governors
