title: THE PNEUMOCOCCAL IMMUNISATION PROGRAMME
text:
THE PNEUMOCOCCAL IMMUNISATION PROGRAMMEth
9 June 2005 
 
MANDATORY SURVEILLANCE OF 
METHICILLIN RESISTANT 
 
STAPHYLOCOCCUS AUREUS (MRSA) 
 
BACTERAEMIAS 
 
From the Chief  
Dear Colleague  
 
Medical Officer and  
We are writing to inform you of changes to 
the Chief Nursing  
the mandatory surveillance system for 
Staphylococcus aureus since our previous 
Officer  
1
communication on 9 June 2003 . These 
 
changes will provide a better evidence base 
Sir Liam Donaldson 
for national policy and will help you better MSc,MD,FRCS(Ed),FRCP,FFPHM 
 
interpret your local situation so that you can 
Professor Christine Beasley CBE  
take appropriate targeted action to control 
RN  
these infections. 
 
 
Richmond House 
Mandatory surveillance of MRSA 79 Whitehall 
London  SW1A 2NS 
bacteraemias by acute NHS hospital Trusts 
 
began in April 2001 and we have now 
PL/CMO/2005/4, PL/CNO/2005/4 
published over three years’ data. The 
 
Secretary of State for Health announced in 
For action 
March that these data will now be published • Chief Executives of NHS acute hospital Trusts and 
NHS Foundation Trusts for circulation to all Medical 
six-monthly rather than annually. The first 
Microbiologists, Directors of Infection Prevention and 
six monthly data-set was published on 7 
Control and Infection Control Teams. 
March 2005, together with the previous • Chief Executives of Strategic Health Authorities to 
circulate to SHA Performance Improvement and 
three years’ data set out in six monthly 
Nursing leads 
format. These tables can be consulted at 
 
www.dh.gov.uk. The mandatory surveillance 
For information 
• Chief Executives of PCTs 
scheme has provided key information 
• Medical and Nursing Directors of NHS acute hospital 
enabling the Department of Health and local 
Trusts and NHS Foundation Trusts  
NHS Trusts to focus on this important area 
• Regional Directors of Public Health 
of healthcare. Infection control teams, 
• HPA – Chief Executive 
• HPA - Director of CDSC 
consultant microbiologists and all others 
• HPA - Director of Local and Regional Services to 
involved in the collection and analysis of this 
circulate to Regional Epidemiologists, Regional 
data are to be congratulated.  
Microbiologists and CCDCs 
• HPA – Director of Specialist and Reference 
 
Laboratories 
With your help we are currently 
 
implementing a raft of interventions aimed at 
Authorised by the Department of Health:  
reducing the risk of patients acquiring a 
Gateway no. 5050 
2, 3,4
healthcare associated infection . So that 
ROCR/OR/0037/002/FTSCH6 
we can all measure progress on achieving  
 
this aim, it is vital that we have good quality 
 
surveillance data on healthcare associated 
 
infections. We cannot emphasise enough 
 
how important this is to help minimise the 
 
risk of infection to patients, staff and visitors 
 
to our hospitals. 
 
 
 1Monthly and quarterly mandatory reporting of MRSA bacteraemias  
 
The first step towards a more comprehensive surveillance of MRSA bacteraemias is to extend 
the current quarterly reporting system, to include mandatory monthly reporting of MRSA 
bacteraemia data collected from 1 April 2005. The reports for MRSA data covering April and 
th
May should be submitted by 15 June and for all months onwards by the 15 of the following 
month. We must emphasise that these dates must be met. The existing reports on a 
quarterly basis will continue. A full description of what should be reported on a monthly and 
quarterly basis is presented in the Annexe.  
 
Mandatory reporting of MRSA bacteraemias is already a condition of the Terms of Authorisation 
for NHS Foundation Trusts. Monitor (Independent Regulator of NHS Foundation Trusts) 
supports the introduction of a monthly supply of data in controlling and reducing the spread of 
MRSA bacteraemias. Retrospective approval is being sought from ROCR.  
 
Mandatory Enhanced MRSA Bacteraemia Surveillance Scheme – Electronic Reporting  
 
We have asked the Health Protection Agency to develop a new enhanced reporting system for 
MRSA bacteraemia surveillance, which will allow the capture of more comprehensive data on 
MRSA. We believe this enhanced system will be helpful in giving Trusts a more accurate picture 
of their performance and in building up a better evidence base for prevention of infections. 21 
Trusts are already using this system on a pilot basis in preparation for rolling out to all acute 
Trusts by October. A more detailed description of the aims and content of this enhanced 
reporting scheme for MRSA is given in the Annex.   
 
MRSA Bacteraemia Surveillance User Survey  
 
Directors of Infection Prevention and Control, Infection Control Teams and Consultant 
Microbiologists recently took part in the Health Protection Agency’s MRSA Bacteraemia 
Surveillance User Survey. The final report will be sent to you very shortly. It is clear from the 
results of this survey that many of you would welcome these changes to the existing mandatory 
scheme for MRSA bacteraemia surveillance. It is also clear that many of you are already 
collecting additional data, such as the probable place of acquisition of infection.  
 
Actions 
 
• Acute NHS Trust and NHS Foundation Trust Chief Executives: You should bring to 
the attention of your Directors of Infection Prevention and Control, consultant 
microbiologists and infection control teams the guidance on more frequent 
reporting now required for the mandatory surveillance of healthcare associated 
infections as set out in the Annex to this letter. 
 
• SHA Chief Executives: You should bring to the attention of Performance and 
Improvement leads the requirement for SHAs to ensure that acute Trusts within 
each SHA area are supplying the HPA with data to the criteria and timing set out in 
the Annex.  
 
 
 
 2The enhancements that are being introduced over the next few months will generate a more 
detailed and informative evidence base on the incidence of Staphylococcus aureus 
bacteramias. This will be vital in meeting the national target of a 50% reduction in MRSA 
5
bacteraemias in acute Trusts by March 2008 .  We cannot emphasise enough how important 
this is in the fight to minimise the risk of infection to patients in future.  
 
 
 
 
Sir Liam Donaldson    Professor Christine Beasley 
Chief Medical Officer    Chief Nursing Officer 
 
 
 
 
 
 
References 
 
1. PL/CMO/2003/4, PL/CNO/2003/4,  Surveillance of Healthcare Associated Infections; 9 June 2003. 
2. Winning Ways – working together to reduce healthcare associated infection in England – report from the 
Chief Medical Officer, DH, December 2003 
3. Towards cleaner hospitals and lower rates of infection – a summary of action, DH, July 2004 
4. A Matron’s Charter: An Action Plan for Cleaner Hospitals, DH, October 2004 
5. Letter from John Bacon, DH Director for Health and Social Care Delivery, and Christine Beasley, Chief 
Nursing Officer, Gateway ref. 4104, Healthcare Associated Infection and Hospital Cleanliness, 5 November 
2004.   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
For further information, please contact: Further copies of resources including this letter can be 
 ordered via: 
Andrew Pearson (Data issues)  
Health Protection Agency  Department of Health Publications: 
Centre for Infections  Email: doh@prolog.uk.com 
61 Colindale Avenue  Telephone: 08701 555 455 
London NW9 5HT Or write to Department of Health 
 PO Box 777, London SE1 6XH 
Patrick Hennessy (Policy issues)   
Department of Health  This letter is also available at:  
Room 210A   
Skipton House http://www.dh.gov.uk/AboutUs/HeadsOfProfession/Chief
80 London Road MedicalOfficer/CMOletters/fs/en 
London SE1 6LH 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3ANNEX: MANDATORY SURVEILLANCE OF METHICILLIN RESISTANT 
STAPHYLOCOCCUS AUREUS (MRSA) BACTERAEMIAS  
 
Monthly and quarterly mandatory reporting of MRSA bacteraemia 
 
The results of the recent user survey of the MRSA bacteraemia mandatory surveillance 
scheme, to be published shortly, indicate that there are some variations remaining between 
Trusts in the interpretation of the criteria for reporting. It is vitally important that reports from 
different Trusts are based on the use of an identical definition. We attach the highest 
importance to removing any remaining variations in reporting between Trusts. Chief Executives 
have the responsibility to ensure that reporting from their Trusts meets these criteria.  
 
We must emphasise that any report of MRSA data must include all MRSA positive blood 
cultures detected in the laboratories, whether clinically significant or not, whether treated or not, 
whether acquired in the Trust or elsewhere.  
 
The data that we require to be reported monthly by microbiology laboratories to the Health 
th
Protection Agency by the 15 of the following month are:  
 
• Total number of MRSA positive blood cultures. (The data will not be validated at this 
stage.)  
 
The data that we require to be reported quarterly by microbiology laboratories to the Health 
Protection Agency are:  
 
• Total number of MRSA positive blood culture episodes. 
 Repeat reports in the same individual within 14 days of the first report are considered to 
 be part of the original episode and should not be reported. Duplicate reports that are 
 more than 14 days apart from the first report of that episode should be reported, as these 
 are considered to be a separate episode.   
• Total number of Staphylococcus aureus positive blood culture episodes. 
 Repeat reports in the same individual within 14 days of the first report are considered to 
 be part of the original episode and should not be reported. Duplicate reports that are 
 more than 14 days apart from the first report of that episode should be reported, as these 
 are considered to be a separate episode. 
• Total number of positive blood culture sets.  
• Total number of blood cultures (sets taken, not individual bottles).  
 
All data reported on a quarterly basis must be validated. This data will be used to inform the 
monthly tracking of progress towards the Trust MRSA target.  
 
Mandatory Enhanced MRSA Bacteraemia Surveillance Scheme – Electronic Reporting 
 
The aim of the enhanced MRSA surveillance scheme is to respond to the experiences of Trusts 
as shown by the user survey. We regard these enhancements as a positive response to the 
comments that have been received from those contributing to the S. aureus mandatory 
surveillance system. The enhanced reporting system enables reports to be entered in ‘real time’ 
as they occur, and allow reports to be expanded in ways that will generate better information 
about the incidence and risks of infection.  
 
 4A number of Trusts have expressed concern that the surveillance system as it currently 
operates does not show the proportion of reported MRSA bacteraemias that were contracted 
before admission to their Trust.  The enhanced system allows for the separation of reports 
identified within 48 hours of admission from those acquired during the current admission. 
However, Trusts should under no situation use a similar rule to select reports for the existing 
mandatory surveillance of MRSA bacteraemia.  
 
The enhanced system will also allow Trusts to specify the department or specialism where the 
patient was being treated when the infection was identified.  
 
21 Trusts are already operating this system on a trial basis to facilitate its development and 
enable a rollout to all acute Trusts by October.  
 
Role of the Health Protection Agency 
 
Policy on the reporting and detailed requirements of the mandatory surveillance systems for 
healthcare associated infections is set by the Department of Health. NHS Trusts, usually via 
their Directors of Infection Prevention and Control, consultant microbiologists or infection control 
teams submit surveillance data to their Regional HPA who validate, collate the information and 
 
carry out some regional analyses. SHAs ensure that the NHS provides the information to the 
HPA to the criteria and timescale required.   
 
The Regional HPA also forward information to the HPA Centre for Infection who perform and 
publish national analyses and forward Trust specific data to the Department of Health. This is 
then published on the CMO’s website. Bacterial isolates with exceptional resistance or 
representatives of suspected hospital outbreaks can be sent to the Centre for Infection’s 
reference laboratories for investigation. This flow of information and bacteria for reference 
investigation should continue.  
 
 5
THE PNEUMOCOCCAL IMMUNISATION PROGRAMME

					Replying to Thread: Birds Feeding

					Created On Mon November 15, 2004 2:00 PM 
					by pgb 
			


		
	
			
				
					
							

									
								
					
								 
				PLEASE LOGIN TO POST A MESSAGE


	Username:	  
	Password:	  
	
Remember my login 
	
						

						
						
						


						Forget your login information?
						


						Are you a new user?
					


		
		
		 
 
	




						


				
			
		


	 


	
	 	
					
					
					
					
					

					EILEENB
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Sat March 19, 2005 5:37 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								David  I take it both your robins had red breasts? 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					MCLARE
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Sat March 19, 2005 4:15 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								Quote

Originally posted by: dtb
We have something unusual this year,we have two robins,ground feeding together.I had always been led to believe that they are very territorial birds,i certainly have never seen them working in tandem before.





They may possibly be a pair, David!  







 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					EILEENB
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Sat March 19, 2005 3:16 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								If you have a dog, when you groom it please put some tufts of hair outside near where the birds nest.  They use it for lining nests.



If you don't have a dog but you do have hair, put tufts of that out! 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					EILEENB
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Sat March 19, 2005 3:14 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								Dtb David



It is indeed rare to see two cokc robins feed together.  We see it occasionally but I have often seen a stand off between two.  They will both take high positions, point their little heads towards the sky and sing their hearts out.  It sounds sweet to humans but to robins it is pure agression.  Eventually the best man wins and the other hops down to ground level, slinks around for a while then clears off.  A robin has a standard size for territory, I think but am not certain it is an area about 50 yards square.  If you want to read all about robins click here:



http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/h2g2/A3474010



I take the point about aggressive racism - nobody seems to complain (except me and thee). Maybe the posters daydream about being robins in mating condition, shooing off the competition. 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					EILEENB
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Sat March 19, 2005 12:00 AM 
								 
			



	
								

								David I meant Friday 18th March.  I hope I have not said anything that appeared to be racist, I do not like that sort of thing either.  Hatred breeds hatred.  Anyway not many people are totally English by ancestry.



We had a pair of bullfinches in the garden today.  They were truly glorious. 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					EILEENB
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Fri March 18, 2005 12:12 AM 
								 
			



	
								

								DTB   Lets do a deal.  Some of your postings in other sections have caused a bit of upset because of some of the expressions you use.   You promise, before midnight on Friday 28th March, that you will be good and amend your ways, and I will give you the recipe on Saturday.



Can't be fairer than that can I?



That'll fix yer.

  	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					EILEENB
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Mon March 14, 2005 8:26 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								Sprawsie  Yes it is true.  About two years ago there was an item in the press, about a man who found his brake pipes had been cut.  He told the police.  The man took his car away for repair, and left in at the garage overnight.  The following morning his next door neighbour found his brake pipes had apparently been cut.  During the next few days a lot of their neighbours experienced similar problems, so the police sent samples of the pipes to forensics, who noticed tiny teeth marks.  They called in a vet, who said the pipes had not been cut, they had been gnawed by squirrels.



Apparently squirrels are genetically alcoholic, and they are fine until somebody spills a drop of brake fluid.  One whiff and they are hooked for life.  The little blighters like to get smashed at motorists expense!  Why can't they buy their own booze and the corner shop?



The story worried me because I keep my car in a row of parking bays under a strip of trees.  Some neighbours had been putting large amounts of food out, and were proud to have attracted dozens of squirrels to one tree.



Squirrels like to spend the night under car bonnets in frosty weather.  I've seen them going under cars and into house roofs.



An internet search for a humane cure produced the information that in America soft fruit farmers plant a border of cayenne peppers round their land.  The smell mimics fox urine, and that is something squirrels cannot stand.  One whiff and they are away like bullets.  Once they get the messge they go away in search of another food source.



We bought a large pack of red pepper powder, the tiny packets in supermarkets would have been too expensive.  The trick is, put two desertspoonsful of red pepper powder and a pint of cheap cooking oil in a pudding bowl.  Cook it for half an hour in either a pressure cooker or the oven.  Brush the peppered oil on the supports of bird tables, on fences squirrels use as travelling routes, and keep all bird food off the ground. Slap it all over the place, on shrub and tree branches, wooden gates, anywhere.  It took a few weeks of perseverance.  Now we see perhaps one a week.



In Cornwall red peppers are still known as bird peppers because the birds love them and they get them - particularly the thrush and blackbird family - into fine breeding condition.  We buy packets of frozen mixed peppers and put them into the home made bird cake.  It does not cost much and it is cheaper than buying bird cake.



The infestation near us was so serious we got a large tree trunk cut into short pieces.  We set them along the garden border, they looked quite attractive.  We made holes in the tops and soaked them in the peppered oil.  It worked after a while.



Asian shops that specialise in supplies for curries sell dried pepper in half kilo and kilo bags, very cheap indeed.



Another tip is to grind peanuts up small so squirrels can't pick them up.



Before anybody tells me grey squirrels are pretty creatures, let me tell you they get into roofs and chew the timbers.  Unless you take extra insurance for damage by vermin you are not covered.  In rural areas many houses and housing estates have their own sewers.  Squirrels pick up food, hoard it near stream banks, it gets washed down.  Sewer rats find it and go upstream looking for more.  



The tree rats, as they are called in the country, decimate forest.  That is why in our area the National Trust close the local forest for four consecutive Saturdays once a year for a squirrel cull.  The squirrels are shot. Therefore what is the kindness in feeding them so they will overbreed and get shot?



Three trees opposite my home had to be felled.  They had died within weeks of losing a lot of their bark to squirrels.



My policy is, farmers understand the countryside so their advice is well worth listening to.  They know more than I.

  
									


									Edited: Mon March 14, 2005 at 8:35 PM by EileenB
									

									
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					SPRAWSIE
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Mon March 14, 2005 4:33 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								Dear Eileen



Squirrels chewing brake pipes, is this possible? Why would they do such a thing, and how can I stop them?



Sprawsie 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					EILEENB
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Mon March 14, 2005 1:11 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								JC18  Dtb appears to have a problem.  ROFL.  I found your advice good and your description helpful.  Squirrels do a lot of harm to house timbers, trees and shrubs - and worse - they chew brake pipes.  Your advice is valuable.

 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					JC18
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Sat March 12, 2005 9:38 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								For anyone trying not to encourage squirrels and pigeons, you may be able to adapt something I hit upon by chance:



Having no garden save a window box, I fixed a pulley from the window to a tree, using wire not string, and so I can reel in the feeder to reload it, then move it out into a clear space where the birds are not frightened or at risk.



The gimmick is, I've got it hanging under the pulley wire on brass picture wire, so squirrels can't reach, and can't climb on picture wire, and can't gnaw through the join either.    As to pigeons, they are clumsy landers and so they can't manage near the picture wire.



There was a bonus the other day, when a greater spotted woodpecker attended. 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					MCLARE
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Tue March 08, 2005 3:19 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								Hi Eileen



There are things called 'Feeder Guardians' available from the reputable bird-food suppliers like Haith's.  They fit over the hanging feeders to keep out the bigger birds - the small birds can get between the bars.



I've never seen crows in this garden, although I've seen them round the airport feeding off the McDonald's debris that people throw around there. 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					EILEENB
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Mon March 07, 2005 11:23 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								If anybody is considering feeding magpies, crows, or any other carrion, please read this. A farmer was on a radio phone in the other day, begging people not to encourage these birds into areas near farmland at this time of year. He found a ewe, in labour, absolutely covered with magpies. The poor animal was unable to escape due to being in labour. Its eyes had been gouged out, the wool pecked off its back and its flesh eaten. The magpies were attacking a lamb before it was fully free of its mother's womb. 



Last winter our neighbours were feeding large birds. They stopped when my husband told them he had seen one of them bash a baby blue titt against the fence. 



Please, do not feed carrion birds. There is plenty of food for them in the wild. Don't make the lambs or small birds suffer. They are part of God's creation. Come to think of it so are sewer rats, house flies, blow flies, bed bugs, fleas. We don't feed THEM do we? Sorry if this story has turned your stomach but I hope you all agree we must avoid causing unnecessary suffering to new born animals. 

 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					MCLARE
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Fri December 31, 2004 2:46 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								HI Eileen, thanks for the info, and apologies for not having been around for a while.  Events of the last few days have driven everything else out of my head, as well as yesterday being a sad anniversary for us.



Well, this 'wildlife garden' appears to be bare of any form of wildlife recently!  No mice, no foxes coming through, very few birds, our pond not getting used, our hanging bird feeders not being emptied, yet a few months ago I couldn't keep up with the demand!



Haven't seen the mice at all for the last 2 - 3 weeks, so they may have moved on, or fallen victim to the odd fox coming through or the neighbourhood cats who do come.  So if or until we see them again, can't do anything at all.  And what on earth is it possible to do in terms of 'getting rid' of creatures that happen to decide to live in an organic wildlife garden?  That means no gas, no poisons, nothing like that, because such things can affect other creatures.



We did have a rat once, handsome fellow, used to dine off the food I put out for the ground-feeders on a sort of table just raised off the ground.  But that was the summer before last, so I assume he moved on too. 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					EILEENB
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Tue December 28, 2004 1:52 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								Margaret I have just checked with my husband.  He has studied mammal life privately and at college.  He says they are definitely house mice.  You must get rid of them, or you could face real problems.

 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					EILEENB
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Sat December 25, 2004 11:42 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								Margaret I do not think the mouse on the photograph you sent me is a wood mouse (also known as a long tailed field mouse). Wood mice have dark brown fur above, silvery grey fur below, and large ears and large protruding eyes.



Yours look more like house mice.  If they were in my garden I would want rid of them.  They multiply very rapidly.





  	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					MCLARE
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Sat December 25, 2004 10:10 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								Hi Eileen



No, I can't post it here - tried, it won't happen.  Will try to send you a pic by email.



Best wishes



Margaret



 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					EILEENB
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Fri December 24, 2004 4:23 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								Margaret I have my own resident wildlife expert.  If you can post a photograph of your mice he should be able to identify them for you.

 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					MCLARE
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Fri December 24, 2004 10:38 AM 
								 
			



	
								

								Hi Eileen, no, I don't know what kind of mice they are.  I thought they might be wood-mice according to my wildlife book, but they are supposed to be nocturnal only.  So I don't know.  I need a mammal expert around.



As long as they stay outside I am fine with them!!!  I've seen 3 together at any one time, otherwise I don't know how many we've got.  



We saw a sparrowhawk in the garden a week or so back, dining off one of the collared doves.  The foxes haven't been around for a night or two.



Crocus.co.uk were offering £5 off their 'blocks of flats for sparrows' so we are about to put one up at the back.  You can get sparrow houses either as a terrace of 3 or as a block of 3 flats!!!  I didn't realise a few years ago, when we had uPVC guttering and soffits put up to replace the rotten wooden ones (which had been there for 60 years!) that it would prevent the sparrows getting under the eaves to nest.  Gotta do something to redress the balance.



Happy Christmas to everybody!



 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					EILEENB
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Thu December 23, 2004 7:09 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								Quote

Originally posted by: mclare
We have some mice which seem to live around the flower-pots and around the bottom of the bird-table outside the kitchen window.  I put handfuls of sunflower hearts around the flower-pots and this morning saw a little mouse with a sunflower heart in its tiny paws, obviously enjoying this highly-nutritious snack.





Margaret do you know what sort of mice you have?  Are they breeding at the moment?  If so you will certainly have fun when the babies grow up.





 	
													
							
	 	

					
								
								
								
							
	
								
								
														 			


								
							


				


		  



	
				 	
					
					
					
					
					

					MCLARE
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
								 Wed December 22, 2004 12:29 PM 
								 
			



	
								

								Hi all



Can I please repeat the plea to remember the birds and other wildlife now the weather is getting colder?



We have some mice which seem to live around the flower-pots and around the bottom of the bird-table outside the kitchen window.  I put handfuls of sunflower hearts around the flower-pots and this morning saw a little mouse with a sunflower heart in its tiny paws, obviously enjoying this highly-nutritious snack.



Also remember water.  I've just had a letter from a friend in York, I wrote to him telling about our autumn project, our pond, and he says yes, his pond is a hven for wildlife although it's small, because it's the only one in the street!



A lot of ponds have been lost to drainage, housing development etc.  The back garden 'wildlife reserves' are really valuable.  What we would have spent on another few days away paid for the pond.  But you don't have to go to those lengths.  Any kind of shallow container, a redundant baking-dish, an old bowl filled with stones so that hedgehogs etc don't fall in and drown - anything like that will do.  And you will be rewarded with so much pleasure!  The birds have to bathe to keep their feathers in good condition so they provide insulation during the coldest weather.



Even though we've got the new pond, the birds still like the bowl pond that Barry put in a couple of years ago.  It's an old bread-mixing bowl, we filled it with stones from the beach (washed the salt off first!) and it's just set into the ground at the bottom of the garden.  We also have a shallow water-container outside the kitchen window and an imitation bird-bath at the side...and all of them get used!



We will be having a very quiet Christmas, going down to a local nature reserve on the estuary on Christmas morning, watching the migrant birds, while the leg of lamb cooks in our absence!  The beauty of getting to our age and being together is - do as we please, don't feel we have to fulfil anyone else's expectations, don't feel hassled to do things 'just because it's Christmas and it's expected'.  We went to a lovely carol service at church on Sunday, I think one of the nicest I've ever been to, with soup and mince-pies to follow.  And we've been to all our 'seasonal do's', the family are all in touch by phone and they all know we don't do presents!  Freedom!



Best wishes to all

title: British Humanist Association
text:
British Humanist Association
	      
	
	
	
	  
 
       
  
	 


Victory on   Broadcasting!

 



 






 


Public Service   broadcasters now required to provide programmes about ?religion and other   beliefs?

 

 


We have won a substantial victory! The definition in the Communications   Bill (now an Act) of the obligations of public broadcasters originally   required programmes about ?religion?, but after Baroness Whittaker moved the   amendment we suggested to expand this to ?religion or belief? (thus embracing   Humanism in line with the Human Rights Act) the Government brought in their   own amendment at the Report stage. The law now requires the five terrestrial   TV channels to provide programmes about ?religion and other beliefs?. Where?   belief? is defined as ?a collective belief in, or other adherence to, a   systemised set of ethical or philosophical principles or of mystical or   transcendental doctrines?.

 

   Whatever we may think about ?mystical or transcendental doctrines?, the   definition certainly includes Humanism. Lord McIntosh, proposing the   amendment form the Govermenet, said the need was to ?add a reference to other   beliefs, which would include reference to ethical systems or philosophies   such as humanism or secularism?.

 

   We are now following this up with the broadcasting organisations to ensure   that it is properly implemented. If the BBC, for example, (whose head of   religious broadcasting boasted in a recent letter to the
Daily Telegraph
   of his ?recent success [in] fighting off the atheist lobby? from
Thought   for the Day
) drags its feet, we shall lodge a complaint with the new   regulator, Ofcom.
British Humanist Association

Government Estimates All Over The Place
16 May 2002
Government does not have accurate figures available, it is no wonder they do not have a policy to tackle the decline in our funded pensions. 16 May 2002
David Willetts MP, Shadow Secretary of State for Work and Pensions, has questioned the latest official figures on pension fund assets. He said:

"New figures from the Office for National Statistics for the amount of money held in occupational pension funds in 1999 and 2000 have been released today.  They show that assets fell by £45 billion, or more than 5%, during the year 2000.  In contrast, the pension performance measurement companies show that average values fell by only about 1% during 2000.  One has to question why the ONS figures show a much larger fall.

"These new figures have taken more than three months to compile after I first drew attention to the £105 billion reduction in the estimate of pension fund assets for 1999.  They are accompanied by an explanation of the background to the errors made in previous figures.  This describes a sad history of a series of mistakes, culminating in a decision by one individual to change a number from £290 billion to £395 billion without a word of explanation.  This was probably the largest mistake in world statistical history. 

"Len Cook has made a very full explanation of the errors.  It is a story of bungling incompetence, so there is still a question as to the reliability of their figures on pension funds.

"Ministers have been all too willing to use bogus figures to try to pretend there isn't a problem facing our funded pensions. It is all too obvious we have a growing and serious problem.

"If Government does not have accurate figures available, it is no wonder they do not have a policy to tackle the decline in our funded pensions.-


DAVID WILLETTS MP
Shadow Secretary of State for Work and Pensions
Pager: 07626 801390
16 May 2002

Editors Notes:

1	ONS Release: Investment by insurance companies, pension funds and trusts 4th quarter 2001 (http://www.statistics.gov.uk/pdfdir/invc0502.pdf) " Pension Scheme Assets fell from £813 billion at the end of 1999 to £768 billion at the end of 2000.

2	Combined Actuarial Performance Services' estimate of the median return for pension funds in 2000 is "0.9%.  The WM Company average return for 2000 is 
"1.3%

3	http://www.statistics.gov.uk/products/p502.asp contains a technical description of the error made in January 2002 and a statement by Len Cook, the National Statistician.

organisationsFAQsBasic facts - FAQs and statisticsFAQ searchFAQs by subjectDiscussionspublic forumprojects forum 																													 Contact The NYA  Training and Qualifications  Policy development  Site Map About the Neighbourhood Support Fund programmeThe Neighbourhood Support Fund (NSF) is a six year £90 million programme running from 2000-06 funded through the Department for Education and Skills. The National Youth Agency (NYA) is one of three managing agents for the programme which supports work with young people aged 13-19 in 40 of the local authority areas in England with the highest levels of youth deprivation.Latest developmentsThe last year has been one of tremendous development and growth in the programme. Projects gained momentum and started to demonstrate the value of using youth work methods of intervention to reach and engage young people. NYA-NSF is now in phase two of the initiative where our work will focus primarily on identifying and disseminating the good practice coming out of our projects to benefit youth work practitioners and others working with young people. The first of these is a set of four good practice booklets entitled Next Steps.For further details of the teams work please contact Angela Mulvehill, telephone 0116 242 7473 or click on the section sublink in the box on the right.Young people from the Bolton Woods project in Bradford hosted a polling station for the Bradford and Keighley Youth Parliament electionWhat do young people think?According to a survey of young people participating on the NSF programme, 96 per cent would recommend their local project to a friend. Mentoring; drama, arts, IT, media and sports based activities are particularly popular. The level of support young people received from workers also came out strongly.Source: Delivering Social Inclusion : An evaluation of the Neighbourhood Support Fund projects managed by The National Youth Agency Centre for Local and Regional Government Research,  Cardiff Universit pp. 45-55Case studies - NSF works!The completion of exams is always cause for celebration, but for a group of young people in Sunderland it is a double success as they are the first graduates of the Hendon Young People's Project. The project offers alternative education provision working with a number of young people who faced the prospect of not doing any GCSEs because they were excluded. With the support of the local school, the project worked hard with the exam board to get the premises recognised as a valid exam centre. As a result 12 young people, some of whom hadn't been in school for three years, were entered for GCSEs.The Hammersmith and Fulham Action for Disability project aims to empower young disabled people by providing an integrated range of social and educational opportunities, including arts activities. Recent successes include a video produced by the young people being screened at the National Disability Arts Festival with a soundtrack by the project's rap band the 1st Chancers. The young people have also produced a short animation about bullying, which gave them the opportunity to discuss their experiences of and issues around the subject through fictitious characters.South Shropshire Young Person's Housing Project  Case Study Details  Nature of Provision  Outcomes of Work  Measuring Effectiveness  Partnerships/Multi-Disciplinary Working  Strategic Impact  Contact DetailsContact Details	First Name:JennyLast Name:AyresHost Organisation:Top FloorAddress:Marstons Mill Portcullis LanePostcode:SY8 1PZTelephone:01584 877335Email Address:ssyphp@care4free.net  Back   Back to Top Next>>																						Section SublinksAbout the Neighbourhood Support Fund programmeNSF in actionNSF key factsNYA-NSF Phase One Evaluation Final ReportNSF PublicationsNSF DialogueContact the NSF Team		NYA partner sites																																															      		Eastgate House, 19-23 Humberstone Road, Leicester LE5 3GJ. title: Undergraduate Admissions Office - University of Durham
text:
Undergraduate Admissions Office - University of Durham

	
		
			University of Durham
Undergraduate Admissions 
		Office




	



	
Prizes, Scholarships, Bursaries and other Awards 






	Awards available for students in: Department of History
Number of awards available: 3



	Prize	Calendar Entry
	
Edward Allen Prize	
THE EDWARD ALLEN PRIZE, to the value of £70, will be awarded annually on the recommendation of the Chair of the Board of Studies in History for the best aggregate performance in Preliminary Honours by Joint or Single Honours Historians.Award type: Other Scholarships/Prizes/Bursaries for Students in Residence (I)

	
Gibson Prize in History	
THE GIBSON PRIZE IN HISTORY, to the value of £100, will be awarded annually on the recommendation of the Board of Examiners in History for the best dissertation on Local History submitted by a candidate for Single or Joint Honours or Combined Studies.Award type: Other Scholarships/Prizes/Bursaries for Students in Residence (I)

	
Thompson History Prize	
THE THOMPSON HISTORY PRIZE, to the value of £200, will be awarded annually on the recommendation of the Board of Examiners in History for the best performance in the Final Examination for the degree of B.A. with Honours in History.Award type: Other Scholarships/Prizes/Bursaries for Students in Residence (I)
Undergraduate Admissions Office - University of Durham

title: Leicester City Guide city trails
text:
Leicester City Guide
 city trails

Skip navigation	
	

	
	
			

            	
                        October 26 2005

			

                    


			

		

		
			
	









		

				
					Choose a city
Birmingham

Leeds
Leicester

London
Manchester
Newcastle & Gateshead
Norwich


					
				

					home		news		city trails		local history		by kids for kids		venues & listings		 links
	







		
				

			        

				
				
				    Lifting the lid on heritage in Leicester and beyond - our city trails take you through some of the hidden gems of Leicester's heritage 

				   

					
				
						
									
									
      
									

									Leicester


									       
																		

										
										
									


								


				

			





		


					
								
									
										
										


										Exploring Leicester's Architecture - The Wakerley Trail

										


										
											Former Mayor of Leicester, Arthur Wakeley, had a vision of quality, affordable housing and sustainable communities way back, before the first world war. See how it lives on in the streets of Leicester today in this trail.
										

										

										Read more

										
									
									                                                        

										
										 From police stations to terraces, Wakerley's work is one of the faces of Leicester.

	
									



						


	
				
							
		
								
								    

									

																		                                   

									
									     

									On The Trail Of Richard III In Leicester

									King Richard III was a regular visitor to Leicester, and spent his last days here before his death at the Battle of Bosworth in 1485.

									 Read more

										
								  
								  

									
									
									
									 
									 Exploring Leicester's Architecture - The Goddard Trail

									Get to grips with the Goddards and find the key to all sorts of architectural styles in this informative trail round Leicester.

									 Read more

										

								
								    
								
									

									
									 
									    Get Involved!

									Do you have a story to tell? Get access to Storymaker, our easy to use editing facility. Just click on the 'GET INVOLVED' box beneath the search box on this page.

									Read more

								
	
	
	
									

									
									Foreign language translations are available for some of our content in .pdf format

									Get Adobe Reader

								


					


				

				
						 		
								

								
								Got a story to tell about the old days in Leicester? Do museums miss out your history? Get your past online by having a go with our simple to use Storymaker program. Follow the steps to build a feature or trail and see it online as you work.

            Police Domestic Violence Strategy


    	 
      Community Safety Unit

      	 
            The Metropolitan Police Service is committed 
              to giving all victims of crime a professional and sensitive service.

            The Community Safety Unit (CSU) is responsible 
              for the investigation of hate crimes within the Borough of Newham. 
              This includes racist crime, domestic violence, homophobic crime 
              and hate mail. The unit is staffed by both male and female officers 
              who are specially trained to deal with these crimes. It is also 
              responsible for maintaining the register of missing persons. The 
              unit is committed to working in partnership with both the statutory 
              and voluntary organisations in the borough to improve the quality 
              of life for the residents.

          
		 
            To contact this Community Safety Unit, dial 020 
              7275 5733.

            There is an answer phone for out of hours calls. 
              All enquiries will be dealt with confidentially and the caller will 
              be dealt with in a discreet and sensitive manner.

            In an emergency dial 999
Newham Borough Police | Community Safety Unit

title: Co-East Plus Pilot:  Final Report and Recommendations
text:
Co-East Plus Pilot:  Final Report and Recommendations Co-East Plus Pilot:  Final Report and Recommendations 
Submitted by Project Manager, Linda Berube Co-East Regional Manager 
Introduction
The Co-East Phase II Pilot took place from October 2002 through to 31 March 
2003.  The pilot was a continuation of Co-East Plus Phase One 
(http://www.co-east.net/projects/plus/index.html) , during which a discovery to 
delivery (D2D) interface using Fretwell-Downing middleware was configured 
for four Norwich libraries.  This interface was tested by librarians during the 
pilot project, using live requests from users.  Because the pilot service was 
librarian-mediated and not directly available to users, findings rely heavily 
upon staff evaluation to determine whether speed of response and local 
access to material add value to the overall service provided by the local 
institutions. Residual funding from the original CPP award has supported the 
pilot.
Co-East Plus:  Background 
Co-East Plus, part of Co-East’s larger development initiative to promote a 
virtual D2D network in the East of England, provides a proof-of-concept model 
for access and electronic interlending across library domains.  The Plus 
project team has delivered on the aims, as identified in the original project 
proposal:
 Establishment of a local cluster within the region to test the technical 
and logistical issues surrounding resource sharing across the library 
and information sector 
 Preparation of the groundwork for the establishment of a regional 
interoperability framework, which is cross-domain in nature  
Co-East Plus was a project funded by the British Library Co-operation and 
1
Partnership Programme (BL CPP) and The Research Support Libraries 
2
Programme (RSLP) . The project team, including project manager, project 
officer, support and web assistants, were located in the Libraries 
Headquarters of Cambridgeshire County Council.  The cross-domain library 
cluster was located in Norwich. 
1
http://www.bl.uk/concord/about.html
2
http://www.rslp.ac.uk
    Co-East Plus Pilot:  Overview 
A second pilot phase of Co-East Plus was originally envisaged and planned 
for in the first bid to CPP, in order to test the technical platform and access 
agreement before rolling out a live service.
The pilot plan included the following tasks and deadlines: 
 ZPortal/VDX upgrading and configuration:  Oct 2002 
 Staff training: November 2002; January 2003 
 Staff trial period of ZPortal/VDX : Dec 2002 
 Interoperability Testing: last two weeks of January 
 Pilot/Transport testing:  first two weeks of February 
 Plus Phase II Steering Group  18 February 
 Interim Pilot Review meeting  5 March 
 Pilot period until 31 March (where libraries send minimum number of 
live requests 
Outcomes and deliverables include: 
 Fully-operational resource-discovery and sharing tool for Norfolk 
Cluster, which will serve as a model for other local clusters 
 Training model for other clusters 
 Issues and findings which will contribute to Co-East’s regional ICT 
Strategy and Framework 
Norfolk Cluster 
In designating Norwich libraries as the test cluster for Co-East Plus, Co-East 
and its stakeholder partners have built on the resource-sharing and IT 
capacity already in operation.  The region’s various libraries have a history of 
local resource-sharing, especially those participating in the Plus cluster:  
3 4
University of East Anglia (UEA) ; City College Norwich (CCN) ; Norfolk Library 
5
and Information Service (NLIS) ; and Norfolk and Norwich University Hospital 
6
Library (N&N) .
As is customary, the British Library supplies a majority of the interlending 
requests for HE institutions, such as UEA.  FE and public library interlending 
staff also make significant use of BL resources. In addition, public libraries in 
3
http://www.lib.uea.ac.uk/lib/libinf/index.htm
4
http://www.ccn.ac.uk/site/library.htm
5
http://library.norfolk.gov.uk/
http://www.nnuh.nhs.uk/
6
                      7 8
East Anglia have traditionally borrowed through EMRLS and LASER , the 
former regional interlending systems.  In recent years, as regional 
designations have changed, these libraries are borrowing predominantly 
9 10 11
among Co-East partner authorities, UnityWeb ,  V3 , and CONARLS .  Also, 
12
libraries use OCLC , as well as applying directly to other libraries via email or 
post.
The Norfolk and Norwich University Hospital Trust Library has traditionally 
shared resources with local libraries, most predominantly with UEA and 
13
through ANGLES . Resource-sharing on the national level has been carried 
14 15
out with the British Library , the British Medical Association , the Royal 
16
College of Surgeons , as well as with other NHS libraries, whose journal 
holdings are listed in a print union list. 
The libraries and their respective IT infrastructure are as follows:

and Information ISO ILL by 2004 (DS uses CRX middleware, 
Service (Staff produced by CrossNet, for Z39.50/ILL-ISO 
participating:  A. compliance.  Full integration with Galaxy is

Norfolk and Health Currently shares catalogue with UEA

participating:
Bridget Cole)

13

14
 http://www.bl.uk/services/copy.html 
15
http://www.bma.org.uk/ap.nsf/Content/__Hub+library
16
http://www.rcseng.ac.uk/services/library/about/use_html3.3 Fretwell-Downing, Technical Partner 
17
Fretwell-Downing , a technical partner to Agora and the original 
DCMS/Wolfson Co-East project, has specialised in ‘non-LMS vendor specific 
products that are wholly standards-based.’   Its ISO/ILL-based product, 
18
VDX , is a leader in interlending middleware and is often used in conjunction 
with other library management systems. A newer library portal product, 
19
ZPortal , ‘fully enables the complete “Discovery to Delivery” process-
searching for and identifying resources from the widest range of targets both 
internal and external, and then delivering those resources to the user’s 
desktop.’  ZPortal is integrated with a version of VDX as well as Open URL, a 
form of hypertext linking, to enable resource-sharing.  During the Plus Pilot, 
FDI was represented by Paul Johnson.
Pilot Terms and Access Agreement 
 As the pilot grew out of outcomes already achieved in Co-East Phase One, 
the project team had an access agreement (see Appendix One) and technical 
cross-search interface in place.  Activities for the pilot centred on ILL testing, 
training, and service delivery.  Specifically, the Project Team and Norwich 
cluster looked to achieve the following: 
Pilot tasks 
 Training of Norfolk Cluster staff on Z-Portal/VDX 
 Testing of ILL configuration 
 Monitoring and testing suitability and effectiveness of Access 
Agreement (Access agreement included as an appendix) 
 Staff-mediated pilot of the resource discovery and sharing service 
 Local dissemination to staff about pilot and Co-East and wider 
dissemination to the broader profession on outcomes and findings from 
the pilot 
 Continued work on such sustainability issues, as costing model. 
 Outcomes and deliverables  
 Fully-operational resource-discovery and sharing tool for Norfolk 
Cluster, which will serve as a model for other local clusters 
 Training model for other clusters 
 Recommendations to Co-East Board for carrying forward Plus work 
 Dissemination (leaflets/training/roll-out)
17
http://www.fdgroup.com/fdi/
18
http://www.fdgroup.com/fdi/vdx/about.html
19
http://www.fdgroup.com/fdi/ZPortal/about.html
                    The Pilot should: 
 Provide input/information which can support recommendations for 
future cross-domain work
 Gauge institutions’ capability/capacity for electronic resource-sharing 
across domains. 
 Produce feedback on feasibility of electronic resource-sharing, within a 
local area, and specifically Norwich 
Project plan 
Plan

and give feedback on

      process, issues etc

forward for Norfolk inst. 
Training
It was agreed by libraries and FDI that it would be best if staff training were 
held in two phases:
 individual training and configuration for each library 
 one wrap-up session with all libraries, to review interoperability testing, 
outstanding training issues, and to discuss the pilot 
Ordinarily, full VDX training alone runs from 7-9 days; Co-East Plus VDX and 
Zportal training comprised 4 days.  ISO/ILL orientation took place largely 
during Co-East Plus Phase I; however, the training for the Plus pilot included 
a review of the protocol. 
Although the two-phased approach was well-received by all staff (based on 
evaluation sheets), scheduling four different training sessions created a bit of 
a delay in starting the testing and pilot phase, as did the intervening holiday 
period.  Consequently, after having successfully scheduled 3 training sessions 
for November, it was not possible to schedule the final training session and 
interoperability testing until late January.   Despite the difficulty with 
scheduling and the abbreviated schedule, it was agreed by FDI and Co-East 
management that the Plus Pilot team picked up the training and theory 
quickly, and were able to apply effectively what they had learned during the 
pilot.
Staff reception of material covered in this training period (in contrast to 
Protocols training in the initial Plus project) was quite favourable, especially in 
the case of ZPortal.  The training materials were straightforward, and Paul 
Johnson’s presentation invited a lot of interaction from the staff. Staff 
    appreciated the opportunity to familiarise themselves with the ISO/ILL 
protocol, even if they would not be using the FDI product in the future.  Staff 
felt that they gained transferable skills that would stand them in good stead 
when using other ISO/ILL compliant systems. 
There was some concern on the part of Co-East that valuable training time 
was lost during the interoperability testing phase, in which all key staff did not 
participate.  The interoperability testing phase would have afforded the staff 
an excellent opportunity to work their way through all transactions of the 
protocol.  However, time and workload concerns were offered as the reasons 
for this lack.  Despite this, the interoperability testing threw up problems with 
configuration that could be addresses before the official beginning of the pilot.
Also, it did reveal some gaps with training, as some staff members confessed 
to getting lost at certain points in the transactions.  These problems were 
addressed by FDI, both technically and in the final training session (which 
included a mini-review and on-site testing). 
Procedures (see Appendix Two) 
A crucial first step in the project, especially after training, was to establish 
procedures to be adopted by all libraries which could ensure smooth delivery 
of service and a common level of expectation in performance.  Areas to be 
addressed in setting procedures included: 
 common practice for checking mailboxes 
 receipt acknowledgement 
 response and delivery time 
 trouble-shooting and problem reporting 
 data collection and reporting 
 communication mechanisms with colleagues and service management 
It was important that each library was able to sign up to a base level of service 
delivery with the knowledge that these procedures would be reviewed if 
circumstances changed.  The Pilot  Team proceeded through testing and 
implementation in the following manner: 
Exercise/Testing Phase
i. Each institution to work though series of exercises, requiring 
them to send messages and work through the protocol 
ii. Each library to check incoming messages each day and to 
respond accordingly 
Any problems or questions to be reported to Plus representative, and/or Co-
East Regional manager 
Pilot
i. Each library will select, on a daily basis, requests appropriate to 
Plus institutions.
ii. Each library to check VDX software for incoming requests each 
day and to respond accordingly (it is recommended that a 
response should be given on the same day, so there is no 
            confusion/concern about whether a request has been received 
etc)
iii. FD/libraries to submit statistics etc to Co-East  
iv. Any problems or questions to be reported to Plus representative,
and/or Co-East Regional manager 
v. NLIS to supply van service, with pick-up/drop-off up to 2x a 
week
In addition, the Pilot team completed transaction logs each week (see 
Appendix Three), and in the case of problems, filled in a troubleshooting log. 
Discovery to Delivery:  Project Implementation and Issues 
ZPortal/VDX upgrading and configuration 
This work was completed late in October, due to unforeseen difficulty 
integrating ZPortal and the version of VDX the Plus demonstrator was 
configured on.  ZPortal comes with a version of VDX that is less functional 
than the Plus version, so the issue for FDI was retaining the interlending 
functionality of Plus VDX, while upgrading to the search functionality and 
usability of ZPortal.  The work around to solve this problem for the pilot has 
not been completely satisfactory as using both software requires two log-ins. 
Commercial Zed Servers, Bath Profiles, and level of compliance 
During Co-East Plus Phase One, system suppliers (in addition to Fretwell-
Downing, three other systems were represented in the network) were 
canvassed for their level of Z39.50 compliance.  This information was not 
always to hand, and delays were experienced because either staff did not 
understand what was being asked, or it was difficult to access the appropriate 
information from the supplier.  What was eventually discovered was not only 
the differences in the level of compliance (version of Bath profile), but also 
other issues which might make broadcast searching problematic. 
Discovery and Sharing Technology 
The Co-East D2D model is based on interoperability of peer integrated library 
systems (ILS).  With the potential for so many major servers in a network, 
there is inherent instability.  The use of middleware and a common interface, 
especially for interlending, is often seen as the easier and quicker option, 
certainly more ideal to test proof of concept in a project environment.
VDX
Generally, pilot participants were satisfied with the software in the following 
areas:
 Navigation 
 Requesting materials 
 Tracking requests 
 Finding Materials 
With regards to requesting material the automatic and manual rota options 
provoked the following feedback: 
          “Choice of whether to use rota or not is an advantage—you can just choose 
the holding library” 
“The rota does not seem sophisticated enough to be useful” 
“Rota system is good idea, but authorization status is an unnecessary 
confusion” 
It is not unusual with this type of software for automatic rotas to cause 
problems.  All of the pilot participants chose the manual rota after the initial 
testing period. 
Comments about navigation included: 
“It is clear from the screen what should be done next” 
“Better navigation because we have an old system.  However, in VDX it would 
be good to be able to search (Bibliographic screen) from anywhere” 
“Navigation between functions wants improving.  Sometimes found had to go 
the long way round to get to places.  Should be clearer where you are in 
VDX.”
Zportal
Usability and functionality for Zportal was rated more highly than for VDX.
However, it was considered a serious drawback that an earlier version of VDX 
was coupled with the software, whereas the pilot participants had been 
originally using the latest version.  Consequently, there were double log-ins 
and lack of proper integration sometimes created more work.  There were 
three ways of addressing this problem when conducting a search: 
 One search in VDX, and not using Zportal at all (Staff were reluctant to 
do this as they did find Zportal more user-friendly) 
 Performing search in Zportal, and transferring bib record over to VDX 
for ILL transactions (there were considerable problems which made 
this option unworkable) 
 Conduct the same search in VDX and Zportal sequentially (although 
this seems one step too many, staff often found that they got different 
results with the same search in each). 
Ultimately, there was no satisfactory solution to the problem.  It was 
acknowledged that the FDI portal middleware is fairly unique in its inclusion of 
an ILL component at all, but problems experienced during the pilot seemed to 
illustrate why it is not included in most other products on the market. 
Server Reliability 
Even within the short space of the pilot, library zed servers and FD server 
quite frequently crashed.  There were quite a few Apache Tomcat errors from 
the FDI server towards the beginning of the project which decreased as the 
        pilot progressed. That there was no real hardware budget for the project, 
requiring a temporary solution by FDI, predominantly accounts for the server 
reliability problems. FDI hosted the project on a temporary managed 
service. With a full managed service setup, FDI automates managed service 
performance and reliability checking within FDIs Live managed service 
infrastructure. The temporary service for Co-East Plus was not part of this 
infrastructure. FDI did apply some of these procedures to the Co-East service 
during the ISO/ILL testing period, which improved the reliability.  
For the Co-East Plus Pilot, training/orientation and configuration were given 
higher priority than hardware, administration, and maintenance.  The low 
budget and short time period partially accounts for this ranking.  The original 
project objectives of promoting and facilitating resource-discovery and sharing 
across library domains dictated how funding was allocated.
With the crash of the remotely-hosted server, there was at least an error 
message to alert project participants to a problem.  When local servers 
crashed, there was no indication to partner libraries.  The library holdings 
would simply come back as ‘0’ on any search, leaving the user to wonder 
about resources missing from a library. 
A testing environment would be a potential solution to this problem.  However, 
it would still be virtually impossible to test so consistently that every server 
down-time would be detected, especially in large and complex networks. 
Staff capacity/capability 
A significant issue revealed through the pilot was differences in staff capacity 
and capability.  Staffing in at least two of the institutions had a difficult time 
with keeping up with their own traffic, as well as that generated by the pilot.  
Although the pilot’s short duration probably aggravated this problem, 
experience with resource-sharing among the public library authorities in the 
East of England indicates that this is a common problem. However, if there 
are more participants in a resource-sharing network, this problem is less of an 
issue as there would be more institutions/libraries from which to choose. 
Another issue concerned local Service Level Agreements (SLA) or Public 
Access Agreements, and how they mapped with the Access Agreement 
produced by the project.  Of specific significance was the difference in 
response times to request:  in the case of UEA, a 24-hour turn around time
conflicted with that of the Access Agreement.  This difference is largely down 
to the differing remits between HEIs and public as well as FE libraries. 
Generally speaking, the Plus Access Agreement worked well; it was agreed 
that participation in the ANGLES agreement had predisposed libraries to 
collaborative requirements for resource-sharing. 
Transport
Norfolk Library and Information Service has supplied a transport service for 
the delivery of materials twice a week, free of charge (there would be a charge for a live service).  It had been noted that the Norwich libraries had 
shared a delivery service some time ago that was not entirely satisfactory.
The Plus project had supplied an opportunity for addressing the initial 
problems and testing the feasibility of such a service again.  According to the 
libraries, the van service worked well, but it was generally acknowledged that 
7-day delivery would be required for a live service. Under the pilot scheme, 
the first library of the day on the transport rota was often at a disadvantage for 
last minute or rush requests.  In addition, for some institutions, such as City 
College Norwich where postage costs do not come out of the Library budget, 
a van service would require additional cost.  A tangential benefit of the service 
was the convenience of returning books that had been left at one or another 
of the libraries, or delivering heavier items whose mailing cost would have 
been prohibitive 
Findings and Conclusions 
The definitive outcomes of the pilot include: 
 A proof of concept D2D service 
 Feedback on the use of middleware to deliver such a service 
 Staff capacity/capability for delivering such a service. 
The proof of concept, cross-domain D2D service is a fairly unique 
achievement in the UK, certainly at the project level as well as a full service, 
as most other similar projects and services have only included electronic 
discovery and reciprocal agreements, and not electronic interlending. 
Moreover, the value of establishing channels of effective communication 
across different institutions’ interlending staffs cannot be underestimated, 
regardless of the difficulty in measuring the impact of such communication.
The Pilot team felt that what they learned of other library operations allowed 
them to see ‘the bigger picture’, or have a ‘holistic view’ of resource-discovery. 
However, the Pilot’s short duration mitigated against drawing definitive 
conclusions about potential resource-sharing traffic across the domains.
During this period, UEA staff were also undergoing a migration to a new ILS, 
as well as handling their own interlending traffic which far outstripped that of 
the other pilot participants.  A 24-hour service level response time meant that 
UEA staff did not have the time to wait for a response from other participants 
in the service.  As a result, most of their live requests were sent to the British 
Library, as customary, and the requests sent through the system were 
‘artificial.’  Consequently, the interlending statistics for the pilot cannot be 
considered representative or a sample of what traffic would be like. 
We can conclude, with support from other such cross-domain collaboratives, 
that UEA’s experience is representative generally of HEIs participating in 
cross-domain resource-sharing.  Predominantly, the HEI is a net-lender, 
usually to FE institutions, and occasionally to public libraries usually able to 
satisfy their requests from other public libraries.  This may account for the 
      popularity of reciprocal agreements, which can be strictly regulated, as 
opposed to electronic interlending.  Electronic interlending provides wider 
access to resources both in the discovery and interlending process, at the 
same time that it places more pressure on interlending staff providing a 
20
traditionally understaffed service .
In addition, the pilot re-confirmed what had been observed in Co-East Plus 
Phase I:  HEIs and public library authorities in particular are more interested in 
using their own locally-branded systems to resource-share, as opposed to a 
separate uniform interface based on middleware.  A managed system based 
on middleware would be better suited to smaller, less well-resourced 
institutions, such as FEs, museums, and archives. 
Recommendations
While there are a few similar ‘clusters’ of resource-sharing already established 
in the region, for example in Hertfordshire, Essex, and Norfolk, where 
universities either share catalogues or have reciprocal borrowing 
arrangements with FE, public, and other special libraries, cross-domain 
resource-sharing takes place on a largely informal basis.  Other regions, such 
as Merseyside, offer more formal arrangements as well as a uniform interface 
for cross-searching, if not electronic interlending. 
With pressure from central government agencies to ‘widen participation’ and 
‘inspire’, more HEIs are entering into formal resource-sharing arrangements, 
21
the most recent example to be found in Wales, Linc y Gogledd .
Libraries in the East Of England have the opportunity to use the existing 
framework of the Co-East partnership and network as a means to establish a 
more formal resource-sharing agreement, which could be flexible enough to 
allow for different levels of implementation.  Co-East has already developed 
an ICT Strategy (which calls for, among others, a regional compliance to 
22
Z39.50 profile standard) , which includes options for including libraries, 
museums, and archives in a regional network. 
The following are recommendations for promoting furthering regional cross-
domain discovery and sharing: 
 With the support of the East of England Museums, Libraries, and 
Archives Council (EEMLAC), a regional access agreement can be 
established, using Inspire and other models (Merseyside and Libraries 
20
see Barriers to Resource Sharing in HE Libraries  
http://www.rslp.ac.uk/circs/2002/report.htm;
http://www.sconul.ac.uk/event_conf/interconsortia2002/Harris.ppt)
21
http://www.bangor.ac.uk/is/library/linc.html
22
http://www.co-east.net/documents/co-east_ict_report.pdf
  Together: Liverpool Learning Partnership and Merseyside Libraries 
23
Public Partnership
 Those libraries with zed-compliant systems could swap IP addresses, 
allowing staff to simultaneously search a number of institutions at the 
same time.   As noted before, there is already borrowing across 
domains; this would make it easier on staff
 In conjunction with such organisations as EEMLAC and JISC’s Eastern 
Region’s Centre, cost effective electronic access to electronic 
resource-sharing for smaller, less well-resourced institutions, such as 
FE colleges, museums, and archives, should be established 
 The existing Co-East management structure (subscription-based 
membership, management team) can be used to support and facilitate 
the above activities, and work with the respective domains to enable 
greater communication and partner-ship working. 
23
http://www.merseylibraries.org/about.html
Co-East Plus Pilot:  Final Report and Recommendations
