title: BestofBiz: the Business Information Site
text:
BestofBiz: the Business Information Site


			Search			




	 Home	 Current Awareness	 Management Insights	 Research Tools	 Site Map	 About Us


	 Research Tools	
	General resources on banking systems and banking statistics




 


Bank for International Settlements, Central Banks and Regulatory Bodies

A good information source for each economy’s banking sector is the Central Bank for that country. The Bank for International Settlements, which describes itself as “an international organisation which fosters cooperation among central banks and other agencies in pursuit of monetary and financial stability” (often shortened to “the central bank for central banks” by others) has on its web site with a page of links to worldwide central banks, which can be a quick way to identify the central bank for each country if you are not familiar with the correct designation – for example, for Malaysia it identifies Bank Negara Malaysia as the central bank, for Singapore the central bank is the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), for Finland, it’s the Suomen Pankki and for Sweden the Sveriges Riksbank.
 

It also posts on its website its large library of publications, some of which are key data sources. For example:	

The Annual Report of the BIS includes a review of the global economic and financial situation.
	

The Quarterly Review: International Banking and Financial Market Developments and the BIS Consolidated International Banking Statistics are key sources on cross-border banking activity and on the international OTC derivatives markets, as well as presenting data on international and domestic securities markets.



The BIS also publishes the Triennial Central Bank Survey of Foreign Exchange and Derivatives Market Activity; the “Red Book” or Statistics on payment and settlement systems in selected countries (covering G10 and other major economies); and offers links to 

payments systems reviews for particular countries compiled by its own committees (e.g. the “Green Book” on Africa) or by other associations of central banks (such as CEMLA’s the “Yellow Book” for Latin America.  Additionally it publishes many useful papers on a range of topical subjects such as financial conglomerates, consolidation in financial services, and the global institutional asset management industry



While on the central banks theme, another good resource is the series of Handbooks from the 
Bank of England’s Centre for Central Banking Studies. These handbooks cover a range of topics clearly and concisely.  For example there are handbooks on Primary Dealers in Government Securities Markets, The Payments System, Financial Derivatives, Basic Bond Analysis and Banking and Monetary Statistics.




A SELECTION OF USEFUL NON-CENTRAL BANK REGULATORY WEB SITES:




Canada Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions (OSFI)

The OSFI regulates banks, insurers and pensions. Under the Deposit-Taking Institutions link on its web site are published detailed financial data for the Canadian activities of Banks, Foreign Bank Branches, Trust and Loan Companies, and Cooperatives (specifically quarterly Summary Income Statement, Capital Adequacy, Impaired Assets and Off-balance sheet items data, and monthly Consolidated Balance Sheet data)




US Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC)

The FDIC publishes on its web site a good deal of data. Its role is to supervise about 5,300 state chartered banks and savings banks that are not members of the Federal Reserve System. This is over half the institutions in the US banking system, typically the smaller banks. Banks in the US can be either state chartered or national banks. State chartered banks can choose whether or not to join the Federal Reserve System (if they do so their regulator is the Federal Reserve, which also supervises bank holding companies). National banks are supervised by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC), and the Office of Thrift Supervision (OTS) supervises all federally and many state chartered savings associations and savings banks (thrifts).



The FDIC publishes on its web site a lot of statistics and bank data. Its role is to supervise over 5,000 banks and savings banks, more than half of the institutions in the US banking system. In the US banks can be chartered by the states or by the federal government (by either the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC), or if a savings bank, by the Office of Thrift Supervision (OTS)). Banks chartered by a state can choose whether or not to join the Federal Reserve System (if they do so their supervisor is the Federal Reserve). Banks that are chartered by the states and that do not join the Federal Reserve System have the FDIC as their primary federal regulator.



The FDIC Institution Directory (found by following the Industry Analysis > Bank Data & Statistics links from the home page) provides comprehensive financial and demographic data for every FDIC-insured institution, including the most recent quarterly financial statements and details on branch locations. Other useful tools are the Deposit Market Share Report (access by geographies down to zip code level), and the Statistics on Depository Institutions (SDI) databank (allowing generation of detailed reports for institutions or sets of institutions).




National Information Centre of the Federal Reserve

For institutions not regulated by the FDIC, you need to check the National Information Centre (NIC) database of the Federal Reserve.  The NIC presents comprehensive information on banks and other institutions for which the Federal Reserve has a supervisory, regulatory, or research interest including both domestic and foreign banking organizations operating in the U.S. The NIC includes the organizational structure of financial institutions and financial information for some of those institutions. Historical information is available on the structure of all the institutions.



Between them the central bank and regulator (if different to the central bank) and National Statistical Office will furnish detailed data measuring that country’s banking system at least on an aggregate level, and sometimes, as we have seen, down to the individual institution level. Very often the key statistical publications are also made available, wholly or in part, in English (a good example of this is the web site of the Deutsche Bundesbank).



OTHER SUPRANATIONAL BANKING, MONETARY & DEVELOPMENT ORGANIZATIONS



European Central Bank

Statistics on the monetary system of the Euro area; additional reviews and statistics of the banking systems of the EU (for example the Structural Analysis of the EU Banking Sector 2002); also working papers series on macro economic topics.


International Monetary Fund (IMF)

International Financial Statistics (monthly) macro financial and economic data for most countries of the world, presenting information in country tables and in tables of area and world aggregates. In addition to the monthly journal the IFS is now available over the internet, as well as through third party vendors such as Thomson Datastream.


OECD

Financial Markets, Insurance and Pensions web site gives Financial Market Trends analysis and statistics on financial matters of topical interest or longer-term developments in specific financial sectors, published twice a year with each issue providing a brief update of trends and prospects in the international and major domestic financial markets; Bank Profitability: Financial Statements of Banks 2002 based on financial statements of banks the database covers 30 OECD countries for the period from 1979 onwards with some supplementary information on the number of reporting banks, their branches and staff also included.



World Bank

Financial Structure and Economic Development Conference 2001, with papers on financial structures around the world, and a handy database of financial sector indicators for each economy over time (updated in 2003 with datapoints for 2001; unites a range of indicators that measure the size, activity, and efficiency of financial intermediaries and markets).

On to next section>

title: History of Paisley's darkest moments
text:
History of Paisley's darkest momentsHistory of Paisley's darkest moments


		'Mrs Adams first raised concerns regarding FCB in the House of Commons at the request of Strathclyde Police. The fact that £320,000 is now missing [from the company] fully justifies those concerns.'

A Labour party source.	




The tragic death of MP Gordon McMaster has cast a long political shadow
 
By Jason Allardyce in the Scotsman 19 th August 1997


EVEN after Tommy Graham pointed the finger of blame for smearing Gordon McMaster towards him, the Renfrewshire councillor Paul Mack never faltered in his staunch and vocal support for the Renfrewshire West MP he first befriended nearly 15 years ago.  The independent councillor, described by the Labour chief whip Nick Brown yesterday as "a known opponent of the Labour Party", said Mr Graham's reported attempt to deflect the blame for the gay and AIDS rumours was based on a misunderstanding. 
 Indeed, Mr Mack, who first told his side of the story to The Scotsman  yesterday, leapt to the MP's defence at a press conference yesterday, claiming Mr Graham had been unfairly smeared. 
 The bond between the two allies was strong, dating back to when Mr Graham took a job in 1983 as office manager for Robertson & Ross, a firm of solicitors which represented many of his political supporters and handled compensation claims for industrial injuries. 
 Ironically, Mr Graham is now having to rely on its offices to represent him in his fight to clear his name, after he was named in Mr McMaster's suicide note. 
 At Robertson & Ross Mr Graham quickly became friendly with a young assistant looking to build a legal career. His name was Paul Mack, an articulate, ambitious man with eyes on becoming a Labour councillor. 
 As their friendship grew Mr Mack helped Mr Graham win the selection to fight the seat of Renfrew West and Inverclyde. It was a seat which had been held by the Tories and there was little expectation that Mr Graham would do well but on election night in 1987 he took the seat with a 4,000 majority. 
 Mr Mack realised his own ambition in 1992 and soon was deputy Labour leader on Renfrew District Council. 
 Political enemies claim his ambitions did not end there. They claim that Mr Graham saw himself as a kingmaker and was involved in smearing Mr McMaster and two other Renfrewshire MPs, Irene Adams and Norman Godman, with a view to having them deselected to make way for Mr Mack and two other councillors. It is a claim Mr Mack denies. 
 If such a plot existed it did not come off. By last year, Mr Mack was expelled from the party for contesting the Hunterhill ward in the unitary elections as an official Labour candidate. 
 Jim Taylor, a Paisley North party member, withdrew his nomination as official candidate hours before the nomination deadline, as had been rumoured in Labour circles. Mr Mack mysteriously appeared just before the deadline with a completed nomination form and stood for Labour. 
 The role of Mr Taylor, who is currently suspended from office, is to be further investigated now by Nick Brown. Meanwhile, Richard Manser, another controversial Labour councillor with convictions for assault, is to remain suspended after his name was also submitted for the unitary elections despite being excluded from the party's list of official candidates. 
 Labour fear that the links between Mr Graham and Mr Mack, who had a common friend in Harry Revie, Graham's election agent, continued to grow, despite the setbacks. 
 In the run-up to the general election, Mr Mack, by this time an independent councillor and constant thorn in the side of Labour's fragile Renfrewshire Council administration, was spotted meeting the MP. 
 Mr Mack admits a meeting took place but insists he only wanted to see the MP because he heard he was getting involved in a photo opportunity with Rangers players. Mr Mack said his son was a fan and wanted to be involved. 
 Mr Mack also admitted yesterday that on the day of the Mr McMaster's funeral, he met Richard Vassie, a Renfrewshire SNP councillor, since suspended, who later alleged to a journalist that the MP had been having a gay affair with an underage partner. Mr Mack denies as "monstrous" any suggestion that he was involved in this smear, a smear which McMaster had hinted would materialise in his suicide note. 
 Yesterday, Mr Mack continued to taunt Labour in Renfrewshire, calling for an independent Monklands-style inquiry into Renfrewshire Council which has been dogged by bitter in-fighting. 
 As The Scotsman reported yesterday, Mr Mack accused a council faction led by Provost Nancy Allison of dirty tricks. The former deputy leader of the old Renfrew District Council, criticised in Mr McMaster's suicide note, accused supporters of the Paisley North MP Irene Adams of leaking details of the smears. He also claimed they raised concerns about drugs links with the Paisley security firm FCB and about membership irregularities to ensure she was not be deselected. 
 Yesterday, the Renfrewshire Council leader Hugh Henry, Provost Nancy Allison and sources close to Mrs Adams dismissed Mr Mack's comments. 
 Mrs Allison denied Mr Mack's allegation that splits within the council stemmed from the failure of Mrs Allison in 1992 to secure the provostship at a time when Labour had only 21 members out of a total of 45. 
 Mr Mack had claimed the Allison camp sought to oust those Labour members who did not go along with their advice not to have anything to do with the running of the administration. 
 Mrs Allison accused him of bearing a grudge because members of the Labour group took a dim view of an assault on a woman which Mr Mack was convicted of several years ago. 
 Mr Mack admits telling journalists he had heard rumours that the MP was homosexual and had AIDS but he denies originating them. He also admitted at a press conference in Paisley yesterday he had once described Mr McMaster as "spineless and treacherous". 
 He added: "That Gordon and I were political rivals and indulged in some fairly robust heated exchanges was no secret. But what I had to say to Gordon I said to his face." 
 Mr Mack said he had tried to keep a "respectful silence" over the past three weeks since the suicide out of sympathy for the MP's family, and others should have done likewise. 
 "Instead, we witnessed the most degrading, cynical, scandalous piece of political opportunism that has come out of this proud but beleaguered town." 
 The idea that he was the author of the smears against Mr McMaster was being used by those he had "rubbed up the wrong way", he said. Mr Graham, he claimed, had also been the target of a smear campaign since the MP's death. 
 Calling for a judicial inquiry into local politics in Paisley, he alleged the council was run by a Militant cabal and that 11 councillors had relatives with jobs within the authority. 
 Mr Henry admitted he had been involved with Militant "on the periphery" several years ago but said Labour was fully aware of his past. 
 He said allegations that councillors had relatives within the authority related mainly to people working for the former district council while Mr Mack was deputy leader and in a position to address any concerns. In any case, a staff commission had since approved all the transfers of staff to the new authority. 
 Mrs Allison claimed Mr Mack, working with a minority of opposition members, had made slanderous remarks and that police had to be called because they showed no regard for standing orders and democratic debate. 
 Mr Henry added: "The contamination of politics in Renfrewshire has been orchestrated by Paul Mack. I think we are all diminished by Gordon McMaster's death but I don't believe we have anything to be ashamed of." 
 
 
 Mrs Adams was unavailable for comment yesterday but sources close to her dismissed Mr Mack's claims. 
 One said: "Mrs Adams first raised concerns regarding FCB in the House of Commons at the request of Strathclyde Police. The fact that £320,000 is now missing [from the company] fully justifies those concerns." 
 In relation to the fears she expressed regarding membership irregularities, the source added: "These concerns seem to have been borne out by the fact that the Paisley North Constituency Party was suspended by the Scottish executive committee of the Labour Party after they found irregularities in membership." 



 








Return to home page
History of Paisley's darkest moments

title: Microsoft Word - SMOKING IN PREGNANCY SERVICES 2002.doc
text:
Microsoft Word - SMOKING IN PREGNANCY SERVICES 2002.docSMOKING IN PREGNANCY SERVICES 2002/03
1. A further £3m has been allocated for 2002/3 for the continuation of the
smoking in pregnancy initiative (for which £3m was made available in
2001/02).
2. As announced by the Minister in January 2001, the initiative is intended to
provide for the appointment of local champions to coordinate services for
pregnant women who want to give up smoking. The White Paper “Smoking
Kills” set a target for 2010 to reduce the percentage of women who smoke
during pregnancy from 23% to 15%. The champions will help us deliver
this target.
3. We have previously said that the champions might be responsible for:
• liaison with primary care to ensure appropriate referral from a dedicated
person;
• providing a skilled intervention at an early stage;
• ensuring that all midwives are appropriately trained to provide brief
interventions;
• liaison with “Sure Start” to ensure joint effective working where practicable;
• providing supporting clinics or one to one support;
• organising (and providing) home visits/support.
4. The original intention was for at least one champion per HA. In the
restructured NHS, we are looking for coverage across the NHS in England,
with the disposition of champions and services for local decision. It is
therefore for each PCT to decide what local arrangements suit them best
in delivering this initiative, provided that the funding is devoted to tackling
smoking in pregnancy and that someone (or some people) can be
identified as fulfilling the “champion” role. In some areas the nominated
responsibility has been assigned to more than a single individual.
Whatever the local arrangements, the nominated “champion(s)” should
ensure that there are coherent and comprehensive services available for
pregnant smokers in their areas of responsibility.
5. We are aware that links between the NHS services for pregnant smokers
and the Sure Start programme are being developed at local level and in
some areas are well established. We would like to see further
development of such links as more Sure Start schemes come on stream.
There should also be potential for application of the holistic approach of
the Sure Start model to the problems of smoking in pregnancy in other
areas, and we hope that the continuation of funding in 2002/03 will enable
this to be considered. If further information on the Sure Start is needed, we
suggest that contact is made with local Sure Start services, or the website
address is www.surestart.gov.uk.
DH CVD and Cancer Prevention Business Area
Microsoft Word - SMOKING IN PREGNANCY SERVICES 2002.doc

		Exeter Working Lunches
 
	




			

			
						
				
				
					
					
	 
	
		
			
			

		
			
			The following lunches took place at the BA festival of Science, University of Exeter 6-10 September 2004.  

Planet Science Outreach Programme
This session will provided practical advice for science communicators working with schools. Six case studies and their independent evaluation on how to reach out and work with schools that do not usually engage with science projects were presented.  Organised by People, Science & Policy

View report

Delivering inclusion in science communication (DISC)
What are the current and potential barriers that face our community? What initiatives are already in place and what are the success stories? DISC is a new project creating sustainable partnerships between ethnic minority groups and the science communication community. Organised by ACNST and the BA 

View report (pdf 275KB)

Networking Science Festivals
This working lunch aimed to build on previous meeting with directors of science festivals to provide an opportunity for directors and coordinators of prospective, new and established festivals to identify areas for potential collaboration, share good practice and improve the exchange between festivals and other parts of the science communication community. 

View report (pdf41KB)
Office of Science and Technology - UK Science Festivals: PEST or not? (pdf 125KB)

Communicating new science
Issues surrounding GM foods were communicated too late. Are we communicating too early about nanotechnology? Good communication is not just about timing, there are other factors involved. Increasingly, we are faced with science that has speculative applications. To communicate this type of science we cannot just focus on the consequences of applications. In these cases the dialogue with publics should focus on what is driving the science, the assumptions made by scientists, uncertainties and the needs of society in the early stages of scientific research. 

How can scientists and science communicators deliver this approach? Explore recent examples, including the BA and OST’s Cognitive System common language project.

View report (pdf 44KB)

title: Statutory Instrument 2000 No. 1382 (c. 41)
text:
Statutory Instrument 
2000 No. 1382 (c. 41)	 	

Statutory Instrument 2000 No. 1382 (c. 41)The Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 (Commencement No. 7) Order 2000


© Crown Copyright 2000



Statutory Instruments printed from this website are printed under the superintendence and authority of the Controller of HMSO being the Queen's Printer of Acts of Parliament.


The legislation contained on this web site is subject to Crown Copyright protection. It may be reproduced free of charge provided that it is reproduced accurately and that the source and copyright status of the material is made evident to users.


It should be noted that the right to reproduce the text of Statutory Instruments does not extend to the Queen's Printer imprints which should be removed from any copies of the Statutory Instrument which are issued or made available to the public. This includes reproduction of the Statutory Instrument on the Internet and on intranet sites. The Royal Arms may be reproduced only where they are an integral part of the original document.






The text of this Internet version of the Statutory Instrument which is published by the Queen's Printer of Acts of Parliament has been prepared to reflect the text as it was Made. A print version is also available and is published by The Stationery Office Limited as the The Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 (Commencement No. 7) Order 2000 , ISBN 0 11 099303 9.  The print version may be purchased by clicking  here. Braille copies of this Statutory Instrument can also be purchased at the same price as the print edition by contacting TSO Customer Services on 0870 600 5522 or e-mail:customer.services@tso.co.uk.




Further information about the publication of legislation on this website can be found by referring to the Frequently Asked Questions. 


To ensure fast access over slow connections, large documents have been segmented into "chunks". Where you see a "continue" button at the bottom of the page of text, this indicates that there is another chunk of text available.







STATUTORY INSTRUMENTS



2000 No. 1382 (c. 41)


PENSIONS


SOCIAL SECURITY


The Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 (Commencement No. 7) Order 2000

	 	
Made	22nd May 2000	 




The Secretary of State for Social Security, in exercise of powers conferred on him by sections 83(1) and 89(1) and (6) of the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999[1], and of all other powers enabling him in that behalf, hereby makes the following Order:



Citation and interpretation

    

1.
 - (1) This Order may be cited as the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 (Commencement No. 7) Order 2000.


    (2) In this Order, references to sections and Schedules are references to sections of, and Schedules to, the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999.



Appointed days

    

2.
The day appointed for the coming into force of - 




(a) section 11(1), (2), (3) and (11) (effect of bankruptcy on pension rights) and section 13(1) and (2) (application to Scotland), in so far as section 13(1) and (2) relates to those provisions, is 29th May 2000;


(b) section 11(12) (sharing of rights under pension arrangements) is 1st December 2000;


(c) section 18, so far as relating to paragraphs 1 and 2 of Schedule 2, is 29th May 2000;


(d) section 67(3) and (4) (`relevant age' for higher rate mobility component of disability living allowance) is 9th April 2001; and


(e) paragraphs 1 and 2 of Schedule 2 (income payment orders and bankruptcy) is 29th May 2000.






Signed by authority of the Secretary of State for Social Security.



Jeff Rooker

Minister of State, Department of Social Security



22nd May 2000






EXPLANATORY NOTE



(This note is not part of the Order)


This Order brings into force provisions of the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 ("the Act") as follows.


Section 11(1), (2), (3) and (11) of the Act (which provides for rights under tax-approved pension schemes to be excluded from a bankrupt's estate), section 13(1) and (2) (application to Scotland) in so far as that section relates to section 11(1), (2), (3) and (11), and paragraphs 1 and 2 of Schedule 2 to the Act (income payment orders may be made against pensions), are brought into force on 29th May 2000.


Section 11(12) (under which a person is treated as having a right under an approved pension arrangement where he is entitled to a pension credit) is brought into force on 1st December 2000.


Section 67(3) and (4) (which reduces for certain categories of case the lower age limit for entitlement to the higher rate mobility component of disability living allowance from age 5 to age 3) is brought into force on 9th April 2001.


An assessment of the cost to business of the commencement of provisions in the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 is detailed in the Regulatory Impact Assessment of that Act. A copy of the Assessment has been placed in the libraries of both Houses of Parliament. Copies of the Assessment are available from the Department of Social Security, Regulatory Impact Unit, 3rd Floor, The Adelphi, 1-11 John Adam Street, London WC2N 6HT.





NOTE AS TO EARLIER COMMENCEMENT ORDERS



(This note is not part of the Order)


The following provisions have been brought into force by: - 



    
 -  the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 (Commencement No. 1) Order 1999 (S.I. 1999/3309) (C. 88),    
 -  the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 (Commencement No. 2) Order 1999 (S.I. 1999/3420) (C. 92),    
 -  the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 (Commencement No. 3) Order 2000 (S.I. 2000/629) (C. 13),    
 -  the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 (Commencement No. 4) Order 2000 (S.I. 2000/1047) (C. 29),    
 -  the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 (Commencement No. 5) Order 2000 (S.I. 2000/1116) (C. 35), or    
 -  the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 (Scotland) (Commencement No. 6) Order 2000 (S.S.I. 2000/111) (C. 36).

					JIHADI-JEDI

				Musharraff goes on a Trip - Ministers destroy Pakistans Image!
			

			

			
		
		
		
		PRESIDENT MUSHARRAFF SHOULD SACK:

junior interior minister Shehzad Wasim and 

prime minister's advisor on women's development Nilofer Bakhtiar also 

Senator Kulsoom Parveen needs to have her head examined and preferably lobotomised.



BBC NEWS WEBSITE 

Has Pakistan's President Pervez Musharraf "gone nuts"?  

That was the view forcibly expressed this week in the prestigious New York Times. 

Ordinarily, asking such a thing about the West's favourite ally - and that too a Muslim leader armed with an agenda of "enlightened moderation" - would perhaps amount to unwarranted insolence. 

But it suddenly seems to have become the predominant query in the minds of Pakistan watchers from Canberra to Washington. 

The case in point? The treatment meted out to Mukhtar Mai, the gutsy woman from a rural backwater who turned her gang rape into a gripping real life tale of a struggle against a criminal justice system in a state of deep rot. 

Three years after she was allegedly gang raped on the orders of a rural council as punishment for a crime attributed to her brother, Ms Mai (also known as Mukhtaran Mai) has made headlines again. 

And some feel the circumstances now are no less distressing than the one that first propelled her to the attention of the international media. 

Travel ban 

Briefly, Ms Mai was invited by a human rights body in the US to explain the social work she has undertaken since her gang rape. 

Apart from two schools in her native village of Meerwala, she has set up a trauma centre for women with the money that she received in donations from all over the world when her story hit the headlines. 

But after applying for a US visa, she was reportedly pressurised by the Pakistan government into passing on the invite. 

All this at a time when it emerged that she had been placed on a list of people banned from leaving Pakistan and she herself had complained of being under "virtual house arrest" in her home. 

No one quite knows why she withdrew her application to visit the US. 

Ms Mai says it was because of her mother's illness. 

The Pakistan government says she is free to travel wherever she wants. 

But you will be hard pressed to find anyone who believes either claim. 

And now Ms Mai says the government has taken away her passport, so she can't travel abroad even if she wants to. 

'Went berserk' 

But before one starts looking for the truth, let us hear the story of her aborted US trip from the foreign media. 

"The Pakistan government went berserk," writes New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof. 

Mr Kristof first wrote on Ms Mai soon after the incident and has since helped raise $133,000 for her social work. 

Mr Kristof says he remained sympathetic to President Musharraf even after he was denied a visa to "block me from visiting" Ms Mai again. 

"But now President Musharraf has gone nuts." 

And his advice: "Ms Mukhtaran, a symbol of courage and altruism, is the best hope for Pakistan's image. The threat to Pakistan's image comes from President Musharraf for all this thuggish behavior." 

Just as harsh is the British newspaper The Guardian. 

"The move [to ban her from travelling] was shocking because Ms Mukhtaran is a genuine Pakistani heroine." 

"Neither moderate nor enlightened, the crude gagging order has confirmed suspicions that Mr Musharraf pays lip service to human rights but often fails to deliver," the paper concludes. 

Another British newspaper The Independent, has taken the incident to be indicative of the overall attitude of the Pakistan government. 

"The ruling party has vilified Ms Mai's supporters as unpatriotic," it says. 

It then quotes Pakistan's junior interior minister Shahzad Wasim: "People in NGOs (who have been supporting Ms Mai) are ready to say anything for one dinner with Johnny Walker and eat innocent people like vultures." 

And if one is to even skim through what is being said on the issue by US bloggers, it is best not to let the kids peep over your shoulder. 

Lucky 

It is hard to recall the last time President Musharraf faced such a public relations disaster. 

The controversy has blown up while Gen Musharraf has been out of the country on a diplomatic tour. 

He can count himself lucky that there are still some who believe that he is not directly responsible for Ms Mai's continuing travails. His supporters argue that as much in Pakistan is shaped by chaos as by design. 

As such, they say the PR disaster over Ms Mai's affair was the likely handiwork of a "more loyal than the king brigade" that perpetually surrounds the president. 

Once convinced that nothing good could come out of Ms Mai's planned visit to the US, these people simply set their minds on stopping her from leaving the country, the argument goes, irrespective of the cost to their leader's image. 

Some of the more prominent members of this group have already surfaced in the shape of junior interior minister Shehzad Wasim and the prime minister's advisor on women's development Nilofer Bakhtiar. 

Those taking a hard line on keeping Ms Mai in Pakistan can be easily found in parliament. 

"Mukhtaran Mai should seek justice from Allah," senator Kulsoom Parveen reportedly said, arguing that being an eastern woman, Ms Mai had no business going abroad. 

While President Musharraf tours Australia and New Zealand, his supporters are confidently arguing that heads will roll on his return. 

There is no way, they argue, that the president will allow this "coterie of sycophants" to fritter away the goodwill that he has won over the last five years. 

But if no heads roll and Ms Mai's predicament remains unresolved, many may be inclined to start thinking that Mr Kristof was perhaps not being insolent after all.

title: Environmental protection Act 1990, Part 1, Part B – Process guidance notes
text:
Environmental protection Act 1990, Part 1, Part B – Process guidance notesLocal Authority Unit, Environment Agency 
 
Assessment for second revision of PG1/4, Process guidance note for Part B 
null Environmental Protection Act 1990, Part 1, and 
null Pollution Prevention and Control Act 1999,   
 
PG1/4 Gas turbines, 20-50 MW rated thermal input 
 
1. Gas turbines with a non-aggregated net rated thermal input of 20 – 50 MW operate subject to an 
authorisation or permit for their air pollution control measures.  To issue such a permit, the local 
regulator has regard to the process guidance note PG1/4, first issued in February 91 and reissued in 
August 95.  
 
2. This assessment for the second revision of process guidance note PG1/4 has been written by the Local 
Authority Unit (LAU) of the Environment Agency who draft and consult initially on revisions to the 
published guidance for England and Wales.  Revisions are issued by the Secretary of State in England 
and by the Welsh Assembly Government.   
 
3. As there are believed to be only 5 gas turbines* subject to Part B in England and Wales, the LAU 
recommend that the process guidance note should be amended by AQ note.  (*According to DETR 
returns for 1998/99 and follow-up phone calls by LAU) 
 
4. Since PG1/4(95) was published, there have been legislative changes and technical advances in gas 
turbine design, and in combined heat and power plant monitoring that affect the available techniques 
for controlling pollution from gas turbines. 
 
Nitrogen oxides (NOx) 
3
5. Dry low NOx burners have been developed for gas turbines that can meet emission limits of 60mg/m 
3 3
for gas firing and 125 mg/m on oil firing. PG1/4(95) contained limits of 125mg/m for gas and 165 
for new oil fired turbines. 
 
6. Retrofitting new burners is possible for some, but not all, existing turbines.  It is not straightforward to 
identify for which turbines upgrading is possible and it is not envisaged that should happen . New 
turbines are now usually supplied with the dry low NOx burners. 
 
3
7. The LAU  recommend that for new gas turbines, emission limits of 60mg/m for gas firing and 125 
3
mg/m on oil firing should be applied, based on the same efficiency of 30% as in the existing 
guidance, ie for more efficient gas turbines the emission limit is calculated by dividing the emission 
limit by 30 and multiplying by the ISO net base efficiency in percent 
 
8. It was already known in CHP plant that supplementary firing into flue gases emitted from gas turbines 
increases thermal efficiency. More recently it has been reported that well designed and adjusted 
supplementary firing also produces much lower increases in NOx concentrations than might be 
expected. The additional NOx from supplementary firing can be as low as zero to 15% of that allowed 
in the calculation in PG1/4(95) Appendix 2 Clause 8. As yet there isn’t sufficient data available to 
select a suitable factor for decreasing the supplementary firing NOx allowance in Clause 8.  Change in 
Clause 8 of Appendix 2 is not recommended by the LAU at this time. 
 
Carbon monoxide 
9. In the event that an operator chose to meet the new NOx limit by adjusting older technology burners, 
this would be expected to increase emissions of carbon monoxide and other products of incomplete 
combustion.  This would not be considered BAT/BATNEEC.  A carbon monoxide emission limit for 
new plant of 60mg/m3 would restrict this option.  The CO limit is achievable when new plant is 
draft AQ note PG1-3 3feb2004.doc   3
operating at over 70% of capacity. The LAU recommend that an emission limit of 60mg/m is 
included in Clause 8 for new plant when operating over 70% of capacity. 
 
10. As the fuel is fairly constant in composition, carbon monoxide emission characteristics will vary little 
over time. Consequently periodic monitoring is considered adequate to demonstrate compliance.    
Monitoring for compliance with the carbon monoxide limit can be economically carried out at the 
same time as the currently required monitoring for nitrogen oxides.  The LAU recommend that 
monitoring for carbon monoxide is carried out at the same frequency as the monitoring of nitrogen 
oxides emission concentration. 
 
Sulphur in oil 
11. Since PG1/4 was last revised, Directive 1999/32/EC on the Sulphur Content of Certain Liquid Fuels 
(SCCLF) has set dates and limits on the sulphur content of gas oil burnt in Part B and other plant.  
The changes were notified to local authorities in a letter from DETR and the National Assembly for 
Wales dated 22 June 2000 and transposed into law by the Sulphur in Liquid Fuel (England and Wales) 
Regulations 2000 SI 1460. The dates and limits are: 
Before 1 January 2008, gas oil used by Part B processes (and others) must contain 0.2% by mass 
of sulphur or less; 
From 1 January 2008, gas oil used by Part B installations (and others) must contain 0.1% by mass 
of sulphur or less; 
The LAU recommend that limits and dates for sulphur content of oil in PG1/4 should be changed to 
incorporate the SCCLF limits. 
 
Different definitions for regulated activities in LAPPC and LAPC 
12. Since PG1/4(95) was issued, the Pollution Prevention Control (England and Wales) Regulations 2000 
SI1973 (PPC Regs) have been made. The definition of combustion activities and prescribed processes 
differ in the two sets of regulations for LAPPC and LAPC 
 
13. For Part A in IPPC, the aggregation rule becomes simpler and applies to all combustion appliances 
operated on the same site by the same operator.  For example, the rated thermal input of gas turbines 
and supplementary-fired  boilers are added together and, if the aggregate is over 50MW, they are Part 
A activities under IPPC. Plant affected by the change may include combine heat and power plant 
where gas turbines and supplementary boilers are commonly operated together. The LAU 
recommend that additional guidance be added to PG1/4 concerning the aggregation rule in section 
1.1 of Schedule 1 to the Pollution Prevention Control (England and Wales) Regulations 2000. 
 
14. Another difference is that the word ‘net’ has been omitted from the PPC Regulations.  The gross rated 
thermal input is larger than the net rated thermal input by the amount of heat to vapourise water 
produced by the combustion of hydrogen in the fuel (the latent heat of vapourisation) plus any heat 
added to fuel or air before combustion.  For coal and coke this makes little difference.  For fuel oil 
gross rated thermal input is about 5% above net rated thermal input. For natural gas, the increase is 
about 10%. 
 
15. Part A technical guidance for combustion activities was revised and published in 2000.  These 
recommendations were made after discussion with the Environment Agency’s Part A technical 
guidance author for combustion plant. 
 
 
COSTS AND BENEFITS 
 
Nitrogen Oxides 
Benefits 
16. Nitrogen oxides affect human health directly. They contribute significantly to secondary particulate 
and ozone formation, and to acidification and eutrophication.  Reducing the emission concentration 
draft AQ note PG1-3 3feb2004.doc   3
for a new Part B 20-50MW gas turbine from 125 to 60mg/m is likely to prevent approximately 1 
tonne of emissions NOx per annum per turbine. 
 
Costs 
17. Gas turbines are commonly now supplied with dry low NOx burners for Part A processes and the cost 
is low. 
 
Conclusion 
18. For little or no cost an improvement in emission controls can be secured. 
 
Carbon monoxide 
Benefits 
19. Carbon monoxide is an indicator of incomplete combustion in which unburnt and partially burnt 
volatile organic compounds are emitted.  It has direct health effects, particularly on people with 
cardio-respiratory problems. The main benefit of controlling carbon monoxide emission 
concentrations from new plant is to prevent a deterioration in emissions of pollutants while nitrogen 
oxide emissions are improved. 
 
Costs 
20. Gas turbines are already monitored for nitrogen oxide, water and oxygen every six months.   The 
increase in cost of including carbon monoxide in the monitoring is a fraction of the current cost.  
Estimates of the increase from monitoring companies vary between nil and £200.  Approximate costs 
for the currently required monitoring are reported as 
null £800 with or without carbon monoxide tests,  
null £500 to £900 for current test plus £200 to include carbon monoxide 
 
Conclusion 
21. For a low cost, use of the best improvements in turbine emission controls can be secured for new plant 
by preventing an increase in other polluting emissions. 
 
 
Sulphur dioxide 
Benefits 
22. As sulphur dioxide constricts peoples’ airways, plays a role in damaging ecosystems, and contributes 
to forming PM in air, substantial reductions in emissions are a continuing commitment of 
10
administrations.  The costs and benefits for the implementation of the SCCLF Directive were reported 
in the joint consultation paper issued by the DETR and NAW on 22 February 2000.  The Directive 
was transposed into law by the Sulphur in Liquid Fuels (England and Wales) Regulations 2000 SI 
1460 
 
23. Oil is used as a fuel in only a small number of known Part B processes, and so the benefits of a 
reduction in sulphur in fuel will also be small.  However they will contribute to an estimated reduction 
of sulphur dioxide emissions of 58-61 kilotonnes per annum from 2003 due to the SCCLF Directive.  
 
Costs 
24. Oil may be used as a fuel for some of the Part B processes, and the estimated increase in cost of oil is 
between £0 and £7 per tonne which is considered minimal. 
 
Conclusion 
25. The Directive has already been transposed into law, and the low costs of these sulphur reductions are 
borne proportionately with the rest of oil burning UK industry. 
 
draft AQ note PG1-3 3feb2004.doc   AQ Notes (additional guidance notes on local authority industrial pollution control issues) 
AQX(0X) 
 
ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION ACT 1990 + POLLUTION PREVENTION AND CONTROL ACT 
1999 
 
draft Additional Guidance from the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs 
(Defra), and the Welsh Assembly Government 
 
Amendment of PG1/4 Gas Turbines, 20-50MW rated thermal input 
 
[THE PROPOSED AMENDMENTS ARE IDENTIFIED BY ITALICS IN THE DRAFT NOTE BELOW] 
 
This note is to amend PG1/4(95), following its second review.  The amendments and new text at points 5 
onwards below should be treated as statutory guidance under both section 7(11) of the Environmental 
Protection Act 1990 and also Regulation 37(1) of the Pollution Prevention and Control (England and 
Wales) Regulations 2000, SI 1973. 
 
For the purposes of regulation under the Pollution Prevention and Control Act 1999, the schedule of 
activities, installations and mobile plant is contained in Schedule 1 to the Pollution Prevention and 
Control Regulations 2000, SI 1973 as amended.  The timetable for implementation is contained in 
Schedule 3 to the same regulations. 
 
1. Advances in combustion engineering have led to the introduction of dry low NOx burners for gas 
turbines, which emit lower concentrations of nitrogen oxides (NOx) than those in PG1/4(95). These 
lower limits are to be applied to new gas turbines. 
 
2. Improvements in nitrogen oxide emissions from new plant might be achieved at the expense of 
increasing other emissions. To prevent this, a carbon monoxide limit and monitoring are introduced 
for new plant. 
 
3. Since PG1/4 was last revised, Directive 1999/32/EC on the Sulphur Content of Certain Liquid Fuels 
(SCCLF) has set dates and limits on the sulphur content of residual and gas oil burnt in Part B and 
other plant.  Transposed by the Sulphur in Liquid Fuels (England and Wales) Regulations 2000, SI 
1460, the changes have already been notified to local authorities in a letter from DETR and the 
National Assembly for Wales dated 22 June 2000.  The dates and limits that are incorporated into 
PG1/4 are: 
From 1 July 2000, gas oil must contain 0.2% by mass of sulphur or less; 
From 1 January 2008, gas oil must contain 0.1% by mass of sulphur or less; 
 
4. The Pollution Prevention Control (England and Wales) Regulations 2000 SI1973 (PPC Regs) contain 
a definition of Part A combustion activities which differs a little from that for combustion processes in 
the Environmental Protection (Prescribed Processes and Substances) Regulations 1991 SI472 as 
amended.  
null The PPC Regulations define combustion activities by the ‘rated thermal input’. Previously the ‘net 
rated thermal input’ was used. 
null A change has been made to the aggregation rule under Part A. Previously boilers and gas turbines, 
for example, would not have been added together. Under IPPC, all combustion appliances may be 
added together. 
 
5. At the start of Clause 2, Add the words “Under LAPC” 
 
6. [THIS PARAGRAPH MAY NEED TO BE INSERTED, SUBJECT TO THE STATE OF PLAY ON THE DEFRA  
CONSULTATION PAPER OF 10 DECEMBER (COMMENTS DEADLINE 12 MARCH) ON PROPOSED 
draft AQ note PG1-3 3feb2004.doc   AMENDMENTS TO THE PPC REGULATIONS.  THIS INCLUDES A PROPOSAL TO AMEND SECTION 1.1 OF 
SCHEDULE 1 TO THE REGULATIONS TO INSERT THE WORD “NET” IN PARAGRAPHS (A)-(C) OF THE PART B 
DEFINITION. 
 
To the end of Clause 2, Add a new paragraph 
“Under LAPPC, the gross rated thermal input should be used instead of the net rated thermal input.  
The gross rated thermal input is larger than the net rated thermal input by the amount of heat needed 
to vapourise water produced by the combustion of hydrogen in the fuel (the latent heat of 
vapourisation) plus any heat added to fuel or air before combustion.  For coal and coke this makes 
little difference.  For fuel oil the gross rated thermal input is about 5% above net rated thermal input. 
For natural gas, the increase is about 10%.” ] 
 
7. At the start of Clause 9, Add the words “Under IPC and LAPC” 
 
8. At the end of Clause 9, Add the new Clause 9A 
“9A. Under IPPC and LAPPC, the Part A aggregation rule is simpler and applies to all 
combustion appliances operated on the same site by the same operator. So, for example, the net rated 
thermal input of gas turbines and boilers are added together and, if the aggregate is over 50 MW, 
they are Part A. Plant affected by the change may include combined heat and power plant where gas 
turbines and boilers are commonly operated together. The lower threshold for LAPPC is similar to 
LAPC i.e. 20MW per single combustion appliance.” 
 
’
9. In  Clause 19, delete the words and numbers from ‘Natural Gas Fired’ to  ‘ISO net base efficiency 
inclusive, and Replace with the following table and footnotes: 
Fuel Processes Nitrogen  Carbon 
oxides monoxide 
3
(expressed as mg/m 
3

fired hours per year (from date of initial authorisation) 
Existing turbines operating for more than 100 hours a 125*  
year

fired 
year

year 
The carbon monoxide limit should be applied when new plant is operating at over 70% of capacity‘ 
*Based upon an efficiency of 30%. For more efficient turbines the emission limit (EL) may be calculated 
using the following formula 
3 3
Corrected EL mg/m      =  EL mg/m x ISO net base efficiency % 
      30 
 
10. Delete Clause 20 and Replace it with the following Clause:  
“ 20. The sulphur content of gaseous fuel should normally not exceed what is equivalent to 
70mg/MJ. To comply the Sulphur in Liquid Fuels (England and Wales) Regulations 2000  SI 1460; 
for liquid fuels burnt before 1 January 2008, the sulphur content must not exceed 0.2% by mass, and 
from 1 January 2008, the sulphur content of liquid fuel must not exceed 0.1% by mass. 
 
11. In Clause 26, directly after the phrase ‘nitrogen oxides’ in the first line of the first paragraph and in 
the first and third lines of the second paragraph, Add the following words: “and carbon monoxide” 
 
draft AQ note PG1-3 3feb2004.doc   12. In Clause 28, directly after the phrase ‘nitrogen oxides’ Add the following words: “and carbon 
monoxide” 
 
13. In Appendix 2 Clause 10 add to the end of the third Paragraph, the following sentence ‘ Compliance 
demonstrated when operating at less than 70% of capacity should also be accepted.’

title: Plaid Cymru - The Party of Wales - PlaidCymru.org Press Release
text:
Plaid Cymru - The Party of Wales - PlaidCymru.org Press Release














Ebrill 27ain.....April 27th 2004





	

Wales should lead digital switchover, says Plaid MP

	




Plaid Cymru's parliamentary spokesperson on the media, Simon Thomas MP, will this afternoon call for Wales to become the first part of the UK to make the switch from analogue to digital television. This follows yesterday's announcement by the Culture Secretary to request £300 million from the Treasury to help fund the switchover from analogue to digital broadcasting, after growing demands this week from both the BBC and the independent regulator OFCOM.


In a Westminster Hall adjournment debate on Digital Broadcasting in Wales, Mr Thomas will argue that Wales should lead the way in the digital switchover process as it has a higher percentage of people who have already switched over to Digital Terrestrial Television (DTT) than any other nation or region within the UK.


According to OFCOM, once switchover takes place, BBC DTT is expected to improve significantly in many rural areas, including Wales, compared to the current analogue coverage. This would mean that people who currently experience difficulties in receiving a television signal could benefit from the switchover.


Speaking in London today (Tuesday) ahead of this afternoon's debate, Simon Thomas MP said: 


"At the moment only about three-quarters of households are able to receive digital television through their aerials and according to OFCOM, power levels will not be boosted until switchover takes place. This underlines our case that digital switchover in Wales should happen sooner rather."  



Notes to Editors: 


Simon Thomas's debate on Digital Broadcasting in Wales will take place at 4pm Tuesday 27 April 2004 in Westminster Hall, House of Commons.






Diwedd/Ends.
